content:
Posted: February 8, 2014
												One of my all-time favorite games. Nihilumbra is a side-scrolling puzzle game, where you control the lone protoganist, Born, guiding him through five varied realms. Born is alone, too- aside from the enemies in the game, which are few and far between, every landscape you travel through seems abandoned, deserted. It adds an apocalyptic feel to an already stark and melancholy game.Born starts out with very few tricks up his sleeve- he can jump and move inexorably to the right, and the enemies he encounters are deadly. As you progress, though, you pick up new skills that allow you to alter the landscape around you- colors you can paint on the world to allow you to slide, bounce, stick, and more.There's really two parts to this game- the story mode, which is relatively straight-forward but still retains a challenge, and the mode you unlock after beating the story, which is devilishly hard. The controls seemed fluid to me, though they take some getting used to- one hand moves Born, while the mouse uses the various colors to guide him along. The game rarely rushes you, and when it does, it's considerate enough to provide enough checkpoints to prevent too much repetition. This seems to be Beautifun's Freshman game for the PC, and I am definitely looking forward to where they'll go from here.

content:
Posted: May 25, 2015
												Puzzle platformer, slow-paced, not very difficult. Main mechanic (besides moving your character) is altering game physics by "painting" 5 different colours (with different abilities, which are unlocked during main campaign) on almost any platform.Campaign is short (~3 hours) which is basically a preparation for the harder mode (The Void, ~2x harder and longer), which is unlocked after beating the game for the first time. In this mode, you'll need to employ platforming skills and brain cells a bit more. Good thing is, almost any level can be finished with different approach (using different colours which adds to replayability). Beating the hard mode will unlock a change which will give you the reason to put few more hours into the main campaign from the beginning (this feature completely change the mood of the game, which is dark/depressing by its setting).Steam achievements are not very difficult, most of them will be unlocked naturally by going through both playthroughs. Some requires higher platforming skill and exploration, but nothing impossible for 100%.Fair price, decent length, good game. I was pleasantly surprised. Totally recommended!

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Escaping from the void, trying to become more than you are and risking the world you seek in order to do so. This is the story of Nihilumbra, a puzzle based 2D platformer from Beautifun Games.The game follows a vey narrative series of events travelling from the cold Icy hills through the forest, the desert, the volcano and finally to the city. Each location brings with it new challenges and a new skill to brave them. These skills come in the forms of colours, paints that can be spread around the environment at will. The first colour you obtain is blue, allowing the creation of ice. Then comes the green followed by the brown, creating bouncy and sticky surfaces respectively. From the volcano comes red, the ability to burn some things and  supercharge others. Finally there is yellow, the ability to create conductive lines to transfer power from energy sources to unpowered machines. It's the combination of all of these that will let you progress and aid in your escape from the void.The gameplay is well established as you play, with a "tutorial" for each new colour. The levels are relatively easy on the first play through but after finishing once there is a new "Void" version of the levels, being more difficult and involved. The controlling of the colours is intuitive and easy to do, and if you make a mistake it's just as easy to undo your moves.The visual style is fantastic with detailed painted backgrounds and foreground objects that have a parallax effect. When applying colours it is always easy to distinguish. The soundtrack is one that is extremely well fitting and only adds to the atmosphere. The voice over is a crucial part of the game and it wouldn't be the same without it. The tone of voice is one that makes the player feel safe while traveling and discovering.Overall the game is solid and everything seems to work as intended, some sections seem to be reliant on trial and error. There is a large difficulty curve between finishing the first playthrough and starting the second, it could have eased into it more.It's has a good bang for your buck and the only thing I would like to see is a level editor with steam workshop integration. Other than that it's a great game.

You would notice you eventually will need to mix them to get it done.The OST is well done, specially on the void pursuit.Negative things:-Short: 3 hours to complete the main storyline (but it have a void mode to replay the story)-The puzzles aren´t very convoluted, fews are going to stop you and make you think for a moment.This game has the word "originality" in every part of it, that is the most remarkable of the game. Is a philosophical game with a clearly message waiting in the end. Games like this makes you faith on indie games increases.

content:
Posted: September 10, 2015
												“Ew, a mobile game getting a PC port? No thanks!” You might say. But wait! Not all portable titles are games with simple yet addictive mechanics looking to take your money. Nihilumbra is a neat little puzzle platformer from Spanish developer Beautifun Games. You take control of Born, a creature created by The Void, who escapes to the real world. Relentlessly pursued by that which created him, Born treks across new and strange environments, discovering what it truly means to be alive. He isn’t the only being from The Void that has crossed over however. Every now and then you will encounter a new enemy, each more dangerous than the last. These, combined with various environmental hazards provide much of the challenge outside of the platforming. The jumping itself isn’t complex, but as the game progresses you will discover new colours which can be painted on the walls, ceilings and ground of the levels. The game has five separate worlds, and there is a colour tied to each of them.The Frozen Hills grants you blue, a colour to make surfaces icy, helping you run faster or push previously unmovable objects. The Living Forest gives you green, allowing you to make surfaces bouncy. The Ash Desert provides brown, which makes anything you paint it on sticky. The Volcano grants you red, which heats up surfaces to burn objects and enemies alike. Finally, The City unlocks yellow, which conducts electricity, allowing you to link electrical objects together. Thankfully the controls translate to keyboard and mouse perfectly. Painting is as simple as left clicking and dragging, and doing the same with right click acts as an eraser.Although the game is 2D, the first two colours in particular have a very Portal 2-esque feel about them. You will be using momentum to jump and bounce your way to new platforms, and although it sometimes lacks precision, it isn’t all that frustrating. You will often use multiple colours in the same puzzle. For example you might use yellow to activate a powerful electromagnet, lifting your enemies into the air. Using brown on the floor in front of you allows you to walk along underneath them without being attracted yourself. There are a good amount of well thought out puzzles here. None of them take particularly long to figure out though. The game as a whole is not all that hard, and can be completed in a few hours at most – an unfortunate leftover from the fast paced mobile platform it was born on.Nihilumbra employs a simple, yet effective art style. Each level has its own colourful theme, often attempting to give you a feel of the heat of the area. The icy areas are very blue, and the volcano is red, for obvious reasons, but this also related to the story. As Born uncovers new colours he begins to feel warmer inside, as if The Void inside him is being filled. The main character himself begins as an amorphous blob, but upon entering the real world he decides to change himself to try and blend in. The first thing he encounters is a scarecrow however, so you spend the rest of the game naively jumping around as a cute, raggedy old shadow creature. The character design of the Void enemies is good too, with weird plant creatures which launch projectiles at you, and a huge snail-like thing that erases any colours it slithers over. At the end of each world, there is a fast paced platforming section where you are being chased by The Void. Ever encroaching from the left of the screen, you simply have to stay ahead of it and reach the end. These are some of the weakest sections of the game, as it shows off the lack of accuracy the platforming has at times. Switching between colours quickly is cumbersome, especially when attempted at speed. I would have liked the action to pause when bringing up the colour menu, as I often got caught out without the colour I needed. Thankfully the game is liberally checkpointed, even in the normal levels, so you never lose much progress. These checkpoints also seem to return all of your colour to you. It feels as if you are using some sort of resource when painting, but this was never explained, and I never ran out, so I can’t be sure.All in all, Nihilumbra is a short, but fun, puzzle platformer. The puzzles you encounter aren’t all that difficult, but they do require some thought, particular in later stages. The platforming itself isn’t all that good, but the unique painting mechanics make up for it. Mobile games are becoming more complex, and simply better overall, and it is nice to see that some of the higher quality ones are making the switch over to PC.

content:
Posted: October 7, 2014
												NOTE:  Don't be fooled by the in-game time Steam is showing for me -- I played my first two times through on my DRM-free copy :)Disclaimer: The game does require some hand-eye coordination and patience.  If you have neither, you probably won't get very far ;)Basic options include choice of seven languages and separate sliders for Music, Sound, and Voice, plus mono or stereo sound and mouse sensitivity.  The game automatically adjusted itself to my widescreen, and graphic options include choice of screen resolution, Enhanced color effects, HD textures, VSync, or Automatic settings (which was my preference)As with most games of this type, you don't just save at any time -- there are save points.  Just touch the globe -- the small lights (aka checkpoints) that will "forgive your mistakes" -- to save your progress.  These are nicely spaced, so don't worry!Unlike most of these games is that we have multiple profiles to choose from (three of them,) so we can switch profiles if more than one person wants to play the game at once.If you hit Esc. during gameplay, you'll see a button that says "Resume Game" and three symbols:  A compass, a swirl, and some gears.  Clicking on the gears will take you to the game settings, the middle button (the swirl) will take you back to your last checkpoint (you can cancel if you didn't mean to hit that button!) and the compass will take you back to the maps page, and from there you can get back to the main menu by clicking on the arrow at the bottom right of the page.Where to start?  Well, I guess at the beginning would be best!The game very clearly shows us how to play, without being annoying in any way.  The instructions are seamlessly introduced by our narrator, who stays with us throughout our journey, giving us new information and telling us the story.  What a wonderful voice they chose, and such an interesting way to progress the story!The controls are basic to start with -- the arrow keys or W-A-S-D and space bar to jump. I recommend using W-A-S-D, as later in the game it's nearly impossible to continue to use the arrow keys whilst managing your colors!  As we progress, we discover colors which allow us to affect the world around us.  The game teaches us to use these colors very clearly, so don't worry!  Each color has a different effect, and I don't want to ruin any surprises, so I'll just mention the first two:  The only color we have at the very beginning is purple, which is unusable until we discover other colors, for it allows us to erase any colors we place or find.  Soon we will learn how to use blue, which creates an icy surface where it is placed.  NOW we can use the purple, if we so desire. ;)  Each world area we visit teaches a new color ability, and all told, we have five worlds and five colors:  Blue, brown, green, yellow, and red (though not in that order.)So how do we use our colors?  It's really very easy.  In the top right corner is an orb showing your current color.  Click on it to open up your color palette (see the first picture in post #1 for a visual.)  Choose whatever color you need for the current situation you're facing.  To place the color, simply hold down your mouse button and swipe the cursor over the surface you want to coat.You have a limited amount of color to use, and sometimes it's necessary to remove the color you've placed to complete the current puzzle.  To do so you COULD click on the color palette, choose purple, and click-and-drag the areas where you want to remove it... OR, you can do it the easy way and simply right-click-and-drag. :DDuring my second time through the main story I discovered that we can easily and quickly change our color by simply using the scroll wheel on the mouse!  Whee~!  Happy day!The experience is really the driving force of the game.  It's one thing to watch someone play it, and something else to actually sit back and do it for yourself.  Take your time.  Discover.  Learn.  Let yourself be immersed in this beautiful and deadly world.  You could power through all the scenes and ignore all of that, but you'd really be missing out.The primary focus of the game is discovery.  Find your way through the worlds without being damaged or reclaimed by the Void.  Nihilumbra is very story-driven, and for the most part, we have plenty of time explore and figure out how to solve the puzzles.  Towards the end of each world, the Void will advance, leaving us with only a certain amount of time to get through the final screens.  The use of the scroll wheel to change colors makes a big difference in the difficulty level, but even if you're doing the point-and-click method (which I was the first time through!) it's still doable.Five colors, five worlds...  Before I knew it, I came to 'The End' and was watching the credits. *cry*  I felt so wistful, wishing that it hadn't ended so soon, wishing that there was more...  Two hours is all it took (the second time 'round,) yet I felt that it was still worth the asking price.. . . except that it wasn't 'The End' at all!  It turned out that this was only the beginning of my journey in Nihilumbra, and the true challenge still lay before me.  Now the 'Void Mode' was unlocked, and the focus of the game changes.  We've finished with the main story, but still have much to do!  Every single save point from the main game is now a complex puzzle that needs to be solved, and all puzzles must be completed to have true closure for the story.  There are no save points during these puzzles, and I can tell you for certain that you will die -- over and over again -- before you're able to figure things out.  The story-driven, take-your-time adventure is over, and is now filled with one complex, mind-bending puzzle after another.  Though I had a couple of "how the heck am I supposed to get past that?" moments, I was able to get through the main story without even thinking about about looking at a walkthrough.  The Void gameplay, though?  I couldn't figure out the very first screen! Mahaha~  I admit that I've had to look a couple of times, but I've been finding great joy in figuring things out on my own whenever I can.Am I finished with the game?  Not even close, but I'm enjoying every moment I spend playing. I can't even begin to tell you how beautifully-done this game is.  The combination of story with narration are poignant and thought-provoking, leaving us with a lot to consider, and I found it equally moving my second time through (the main story -- still working on the Void section!)  The music is beautiful, though I found it better to have the music and sound effects half the volume of the narration.  For me, it was the perfect balance.  I really loved everything about the game, and I can't recommend it highly enough!  Two thumbs up!

content:
Posted: September 5, 2016
Product received for free
Basic InformationTitle:  NihilumbraDeveloper:  BeautiFun Games Publisher:  BeautiFun GamesGenre:  PlatformerGeneral ImpressionNihilumbra is one of the  few 2D platformers to which I could find no deficiency. It is a chain with no weak links. Everything from the way it looks, sounds and plays, feels perfect. Storywise, few platform games leave a more poignant impression in regards to the levels themselves which seem deserted and devoid of any chromatic diversity until the protagonist arrives. Color plays an important role in Nihilumbra (loose Latin translation for “shadow of nothing”), since you will face more puzzles than enemies in this game. The use of colors in altering the landscape and avoiding obstacles bares a powerful contrast to the barren levels. While it never becomes too easy, after completing the first playthrough you unlock the Void mode, which significantly increases the difficulty. The game’s asking price is fully justified and you have both Achievements and Cards. Nihilumbra remains more of a contemplative journey than one filled with action and combat. And that is exactly what sets it apart from generic platform titles which fail to deliver a story.  Strong Points+ Interesting game concept, storyline and effects.+ Diversified levels with two game modes.+ Steam Trading Cards & Achievements.Weak Points- None.Rating 10/10 This review was submitted for Imperial Reviews and Cubbes.

												This game is weird looking but with beautiful environments.  You have a narrator to help you in your journey and an amazing soundtrack.  It's basically a platform game with a unique style of its own.  It is rather short with only six (6) sections to explore.   What made the gameplay standout, is the way you can manipulate your environment with just a simple stroke of your mouse.  When you pick a color and move your mouse it paints your suroundings.  If you choose blue, the terrain becomes slippery; green makes it more springy; brown makes it sticky; red burns things and yellow conducts electricity.The game appeals more to a much younger audience but I am still glad I purchased it.  It is one of the best platform games out there.  I recommend this to everyone.  Go and pick one now.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2015
												It's a good puzzle-platformer, a well-done one, with no bugs or glitches and a pretty interesting gameplay concept, but it's still far from my favorites. It's got its merits, and I can only recommend it for them, but it made me appreciate it without liking it. Why? Well, there are some downsides, that many could easily ignore, but for me they were important:- that narrator was a really bad idea. It seems like an attempt to recreate the Bastion one, but a shallow, totally unsuccessful one that rather annoys and feels unnecessary.- the controls are only partially accurate. When it matters the most, like when trying to get the Pacifist achievement, one can easily notice they're rather clunky and imprecise.- the game idea / storyline is somehow just pretentious. Yeah, I get it, void, searching, profundity, philosophy, whatnot, but it never really "communicates" something to me, it doesn't come with any true revelation or original idea. It ends up feeling just as superficial as the narrator's texts.Anyway, I loved the background music, the graphics are nice, and the gameplay concept of using the colors to transform the world is really interesting in my opinion, and captivating.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2015
												There are dozens― hundreds, no doubt― of platformers that mimick this one in execution, you might be presuming. There are plenty of games with an art style similarly atmospheric, others that use colour or shadow as a gameplay mechanic. What about Limbo? Contrast? Why entertain this indie game when you can play those? It certainly isn't the first platformer to capture my heart, but there is something undeniably special about Nihilumbra and it would be a crime to dismiss its own merits because you've met your quota for indie games this year. Nihilumbra is a bleak but beautiful puzzle-platformer, stunning in its simplicity, that struck a chord with me in an emotionally cathartic, personal way. I cannot recommend it highly enough.You are Born, an adorable creature from The Void, who spends the game fleeing because The Void wants you back where you belong. Home. The darkness. Born must run from the all-consuming Void, adapting to his new and vibrant surroundings in the real world, encountering enemies generated by The Void, with ever intensifying (occassionally timed) puzzle-solving. His desperation to escape inevitable capture at the clutches of this nothingness is not unlike struggling with depression and it resonated so powerfully with me I was all the more encouraged to keep on going. I was compelled to help Born live.The story mode's puzzles are splendidly straightforward― yes, this could be a turn off for some― but it does allow for appreciation of other aspects of the game, such as:• The story itself. Nihilumbra becomes less about the puzzles and more about the message behind the storytelling, which is profound in an uncomplicated sort of way.• The somewhat unique gameplay mechanic of using colour to traverse platforms and solve puzzles. With a flick of your mouse you can coat the floor with red to burn away the shadow of a skeletal monster or propel yourself with icy blue across a previously unconquerable gap.• The art. You can enjoy it in game or from the concept art section of the main menu, which unlocks as you finish each level. The enemy design is fittingly simplistic but interesting as well, with an Edward Gorey flair. • It boasts a sublime soundtrack, which is understated but accompanies the game well. • The narrator's voice is flat (deliberately, I believe, but I might be wrong) and ominous. He often points out the obvious and it reiterates how dire a situation Born is in. Although there is an option to turn the narrator off or lower the volume, I much prefer the game with him. He adds to the sense of despondency, but I realise this is a matter of debate. • The aptly named "Void Mode" which unlocks once you've completed the main story. This mode is tough as nails. I would argue that you haven't truly experienced what the game has to offer if you haven't subjected yourself to the teeth-grindingly frustrating (but ultimately doable) Void Mode. It is much more unforgiving and a decent challenge for those who thought the main game was a breeze.Nihilumbra is well worth the asking price and it's a steal on sale. If nothing else, it's an easy, ethereal endeavour that should only require a couple of hours of your time to show you it is not a game to be ignored.

content:
Posted: May 25, 2015
Note: video review embedded below.There’s a specific scene you revisit a few times throughout Nihilumbra. It begins with you falling, the world having been twisted into something surreal, yet oddly soothing. You don’t stay here long, but it was within these brief moments that I was able to collect the scattered thoughts swirling around in my head that I had previously been unable to make sense of.These scenes represented to me what Nihilumbra was on a conceptual level. They’re beautiful, empty, and meaningless. The reason I was finding it so hard to take something away from Nihilumbra was because there was nothing there. It’s a gorgeous experience filled with expression, but its aesthetics are simply a mask with nothing underneath.Nihilumbra tries relentlessly to carve out a philosophical core within its narrative, but it comes across as venting the poorly formed ideas of someone who has given up on the world rather than something profound. The writing feels forced and lacks any impact, obnoxiously attempting to make you feel something - anything - by simply stating those feelings as if that is somehow enough to bring them into existence. Ultimately the constant reminders that I was supposed to feel guilty or scared only caused me to become despondent and annoyed.The detached way in which Nihilumbra handles morality makes it feel as if it doesn’t really care. It wants to come across as deep without having anything to actually say, filling its world with empty words that bounced off me as quickly as they reappeared.Eventually I simply tuned the writing out and attempted to focus on the puzzle designs instead, yet doing this only brought out how similarly hollow and disinteresting those elements were too. Controlling various elemental powers which can be painted on the environment should provide endless interesting applications, but Nihilumbra never even scratches that surface. It provides you new tools at a steady pace but never a creative way to use them.Puzzle designs repeat the same basic ideas the entire way through, often requiring no forethought as the answer is simply a slightly altered version of the tutorial. Nihilumbra isn’t just easy, it’s numbingly repetitive and unstimulating. The only time I felt challenged was in navigating the interface, which while not terrible tended to feel awkward and more suited to its touch-based origins than a mouse and keyboard. But then as if to mock me, completing the game unlocks “void mode”, which far from the simplistic main game radically raises the difficulty with cheap trial and error level designs. This doesn’t in turn make them any more engaging however, as the only thing being tested is your patience and how quickly you can move your fingers, rather than your puzzle solving skills.Nihilumbra is such an exquisite game to look at, that it’s disheartening to see such lovely artwork was wasted on an experience that only manages to dull the senses. It functions, but provides no incentive to spend even a few hours to complete it. Playing it felt almost like it was actively pushing me out, unintentionally but forcefully, as if despite having outrun the void pursuing me it had already devoured the game itself.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2014
												Nihilumbra raises questions about life and existence during its (3 hour or so) story. It's an unique game. One that I really enjoyed. It's a puzzle platformer game that's light on the puzzles; you have to use one or more of 5 colors to paint the landscapes and that way solve these puzzles. Paint the landscape green to jump, paint it brown to stick to the ground or use stealth, paint it yellow to generate electricity etc. At the beginning you'll use only one color, but after a few levels you'll be combining two or more colors in order to advance. The puzzles are never hard and even the most casual gamer will know how to solve these.The voice acting is ok-ish. The narrator has a boring, uninteresting voice. I think no voice acting would've worked better in this case.The graphics look okay for the most part. The environments are just perfectly fine, but the character you control as well as the enemies around you seem to lack animation frames. It all looks really basic and wooden in motion. A terrible shame. A few more frames would've definitely benefited this game. I didn't get immersed into the game and I think it's because of this. It's just too obvious. Anyway, enough about the animations. Nihilumbra is a clever game that all gamers can and probably will enjoy. If not for the gameplay, then most likely for the story it's trying to tell. Recommended.[Rating: 72/100]

content:
Posted: February 17, 2016
												I'm kind of surprised there weren't more indie games with strong narrators released in the wake of Bastion. Then again, it's probably a good thing because strong narrators require excellent writing and voice acting. That didn't stop the people behind Nihilumbra from taking a swing at it, and luckily they paired their efforts with a very solid puzzle platformer.You play a sentient piece of the Void, the nothingness that inevitably consumes all of existence. As you progress through the many regions of the world, the unnamed narrator describes how your little Voidperson learns of emotions and hope and all that jazz. Especially in the early game, the narrator has a real bad case of never-shut-the-hell-up-itis, delivering some seriously overwrought lines almost every single screen. While many of them are the tiresome "You are nothing" or "They are coming" sorts, the writing does improve the further you get in, which was a welcome discovery.The actual platforming revolves around painting the world with the colors you find. Each region you travel to grants you a color to use, such as the blue from the snowfields that makes surfaces icy and slick. Levels are laid out in a way that eases you into learning how your new color works, showing you how to combine it with other colors, and then tests you in auto-scrolling escape sequences before moving on to the next land. The puzzles are all clever and fun to solve without being repetitive or all that challenging. Interestingly, the game keeps giving you new powers right up to the final stage, so there's always something to look forward to.The reason for this is a Void Mode unlocked once you beat the game, which consists of remixes of the base levels. In stark contrast to the originals these start out incredibly hard and only grow more ludicrous. If I have one complaint about Nihilumbra, it's that there's really no Normal difficulty. The base game is practically a two-hour tutorial, and Void Mode is the Dark World from Super Meat Boy. I doubt that most will have the patience to plow through Void Mode, but honestly the two hours I spent in the base game was enough to make me happy. The art is clean and creative and the platforming, while a bit floaty, is a good match for the color gimmick. For charming or challenging puzzle platforming, this one fits the bill just fine.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2013
												Nihilumbra is a poetic 2D platform game.In my opinion, it's very similar to Limbo, but the game  also made me think about Another World and Heart Of Darkness for the design, the level-design and the gameplay.The poetic side of the game is reinforced by the off-voice of the narrator in almost every screen of the story mode.The story mode is not very difficult, and its main purpose is to tell a poetic story, the birth of the protagonist from the void, and his discovery of our world through different and various landscapes.The gameplay is based on the mastering of colours, which have different properties, such as the possibility to slide, or to bounce, etc...Once you've finished the story mode, you unlock the void mode.Here, forget about the story, the poetism and the narration, it's all about thinking, skill and timing.The void mode visits all levels of the story mode once again and modifies them into much harder puzzle levels.It's somehow like the dark world in Super Meat Boy, but in a more easier way though.I had a good time with this game, and I recommend it to every Limbo-like lovers.Nihilumbra has just one big problem : its length.It'll take you about 3 hours (maximum) to finish the story mode, and maybe the double to beat the void mode, depending on your skills.

content:
Posted: July 24, 2015
												This is a beautiful game with a stirring atmosphere and mood. A puzzle-platformer at it's core, it is immersive enough to make you forget that you're solving puzzles or dodging strange other-wordly creatures but feels more like a story that you're enjoying and experiencing.I don't play many puzzle games and I still loved it so don't overlook this game because of the puzzle factor! I found the puzzles to be just right - they were sufficiently rewarding and never too frustrating to solve. The platforming is pretty straight forward and enhanced by some of the unique abilities the protagonist acquires (eg: being able to shoot a sticky-mud thing onto walls to cling onto or shooting bouncy grass or ice to reach sections otherwise inaccessible. There's some nice creativity at the core of this game.Once you complete the main story (arguably not quite a 'story' in the traditional sense but still immensely enjoyable...) you unlock a harder version of the game - same areas with more complex puzzles. These, I safely avoided due to my aforetold indifference to hardcore puzzle games but that does add good replay value and may strike a chord with the puzzler in you.In all - this is an excellent Indie title. You can even try the demo from the developer's website I believe if you're on the fence.PS: IIRC I spent more than the 3.5 hours reported by Steam on this game (probably spent offline) but in any case this is a short game without any doubt, so bear that in mind.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2016
												Nihilumbra is a puzzle platformer, with more emphasis on puzzle and less emphasis on platformer.  I'm usually pretty terrible at platformers, but I'd even classify it as "not hard but fun."  I rarely requires very much precision in timing.  There are places where you might be pressed a bit with timing and precision, but that's certainly not the emphasis.You play with a combination of keyboard and mouse.  With one hand you control movement (left, right, jump); and with the mouse hand you control the deployment of "colors" which change the characteristics of the terrain around you.  For instance, one of the first colors is blue, which is slippery, and if you apply blue to a surface it becomes slippery, allowing you to go faster and/or build up momentum.  There are secondary effects, such as making your enemies slide also.  Other colors have different effects such as bounciness, stickiness, etc.Again, I'm usually terrible at platformers and I enjoyed this, so if you're more into puzzle aspects of games, and less into platforming, I'd say give this a go if you're interested.  For those of you who are more hardcore platformers, there is a more difficult void mode of the game that is much more challenging than the regular game that unlocks at game completion.  The more difficult mode is far more difficulty than I was looking for, but it might be good for those looking for something requiring more precision and quickness.

content:
Posted: March 2, 2014
												I went into this game not really expecting much, just an average adaptation of a Steam game from an app, but I was pretty surprised with how well this game translated, and I would even say that the PC version was better! Basically, you take control of a being created by "The Void", who is searching through the world, trying to discover what he is and where he belongs. Along this journey, he takes control of many different elemental powers, which makes up the basic gameplay. This may sound like an overused story with a basic platformer, but the game is extremely charming and a load of fun. Top it off with the low price of $9.99, a good soundtrack, and an overall great atmosphere, and you have a game that I can't help but recommend. The only downside that I can see with this game is the brutally punishing difficulty curve, via Void Mode. You basically go from a game that even young kids could play with relative ease, to a game that I doubt the developers themselves could beat with ease, but that's not necesarrily a bad thing, especially to anybody who wants a good challenge and added replay value. Just be prepared to be left floored by some of the especially challenging levels. Overall, this is a game that I really enjoyed playing through, and I recommend it to any platforming fans that are looking for a good side-project.Rating: 7.5/10

content:
Posted: September 1, 2016
Product received for free
												Game: NihilumbraPublisher: BeautiFun Games Gameplay:Nihilumbra is a puzzle platformer which heavily depends upon the use of five colours. Your main goal throughout the game is mostly solve the puzzles and kill monsters using the power of your colours which have various different properties like Burn, Stick, Electricity, Slide and Bounce. All the areas in the game has a different colour scheme which requires you to use the given powers in a different manner each time. Nihilumbra is divided into two parts: A tutorial sort of Story mode, and the Void mode. The story mode is quite short lasting around 4 hours and relatively much easier than the latter. Void mode is where the real meat of the game lies. It is difficult to cross, no one holds your hands during these levels and sometimes it can be brutal to surpass these levels. Overall, Nihilumbra presents a different kind of gameplay which is not seen much in today’s games. VisualsThe art of Nihilumbra is very unique.  It lends beautifully to the atmosphere created by the gameplay. It helps create a very solid environment which doesn’t let go until the very end. As the gameplay relies mostly on the use of various colours, the visuals do make you feel as if all the different colours are popping on the screen. It also helps that the protagonist is entirely purplish black which shows how much the colours might mean to him. The visuals are sharp and very intelligently done. Nihilumbra sports a visual style which will remain in your minds for quite some time. Sound and MusicWhile not as exceptional as the above explained visuals, the sounds still do a good enough job to support the environment of the game with minimal soundtrack while you are doing absolutely nothing and some intense music during the final stages of the game. It really helps set the mood right and helps the game grow to another level where it really shines.While it is nothing that we haven’t heard before, it still shows that a good soundtrack combined with solid and unique visuals can create a strong atmosphere.PerformanceNihilumbra has spent time on the shelves and runs buttery smooth with no crashes, screen tearing or freezing at any given point of time. I did encounter a couple of bugs but nothing took me out of the immersion or broke the game. It is a very stable game which might even run on even the lower-end of the computers.OverallNihilumbra is a very good game which captures your attention from the get go and never lets go. It’s unique visual style and a solid gameplay really deserves the applause and it is a game you won’t regret buying. The story mode might be short but the Void mode more than makes up for it. Rating : 8/10

content:
Posted: January 8, 2014
												This game is a mixed bag from first glance. Honestly, the first half of the game is very dry and has copious amounts of needless narration. The narration is so rampant that you have to sit still each screen just to hear it, and honestly little is being said. To borrow from Shakespeare: the narrator speaks an infinite deal of nothing. It left a bad taste in my mouth as I felt the world could speak for itself in most cases. Less narration is more in this sense; the only reason why Bastion got away with gobs of narration is because there were interesting things to say, which were said in colorful ways. Do yourself a favor and drag the narration volume slider all the way to the left. The text alone, ironically, is more immersive since the narrator ends up getting cut off mid-sentence during normal play.That said, the second half of the game is good. Don't get me wrong: the story is interesting, but the color mechanic is the real star of this game. The initial game is mostly a tutorial, while the void stages allow you to get creative with solving the problems ahead of you using the five colors you acquire during the main game. Many puzzles can be solved in multiple ways, some of them probably in ways not intended by the developer. However, I ran in to two major problems.First off, there's some collision issues in the game, and often they can break puzzles entirely. In some cases, they are surmountable obstacles, such as the player's character getting snagged by the terrain. Those same snags, though, can send the player bouncing in different directions when using the green color. It's frustrating to be punished by the game for using the powers as intended.Second, bullet collision is absolutely broken when vsync is on. It took me a while to figure this out, but my experience was tarnished by it. Several puzzles required bouncing bullets using the green color, and often those bullets would inexplicably implode before hitting a target. Some of the collision is off in the game, such as metal boxes, but turning off vsync at least allows the player to finish the game.I definitely enjoyed the second half of the game way more than the first half, so take that with a grain of salt (and maybe wait for a sale), but I can still say this game is decent enough for someone looking for an interesting puzzle/platformer hybrid.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												I bought this game during Steam's winter sale for mere few bucks without expecting much. Just the fact that I've bothered to write a review with a recommendation should make obvious the fact that I got more than I expected. While the gameplay itself is cool (puzzle/platformer with a twist), the animations are great and the music isn't half bad either, what got me really interested is the story, or better yet - the storytelling. The way the game is being presented somewhat reminds be of Bastion. You're introduced to a creature you know nothing about (the character you play), running from a mysterious enemy while discovering new worlds and developing along the way. Just like in Bastion, the narrator's script and voice acting make the game really easy to get into, and so far it seems like it's not getting old too quickly, either, as the game introduces a fun, original aspect of learning and using abilities.That element, as in "the twist" I mentioned on the first paragraph, is the use of "colors" as abilities. Every color represents an ability with specific functions, and you have to figure out what colors you need to use in order to solve a puzzle, defeat an enemy or deal with any other type of obstacle you encounter. The first color you discover is blue. When you "paint" a surface blue, you can run faster on that surface, allowing you to gain more momentum and jump farther than you could without it. As you advance to new worlds, you discover more colors which in turn, give you new abilities. Sometimes it's necessary to combine two or more colors in order to solve a problem, as the puzzles become more and more challenging as you get farther in the game. In conclusion, this game is really fun, and I recommend it to anyone who likes platformers. Definitely worth it!

Almost EVERY screen he has some mundane remark to make. In the few instances the puzzles actually DID take multiple attempts to solve I just became even MORE infuriated because every time I freaking die, I have to come right back to YOU NEED TO KEEP RUNNING. RUNNING AND RUNNING AND RUNNING. WHAT IS THE POINT IN RUNNING? WHY MUST YOU KEEP RUNNING. BUT YOU MUST KEEP RUNNING. I just wanna yell at the guy. Oh my god. Shutupshutupshutupshutup! RAAAA. ok. I'm ok.♥♥♥♥♥♥ Now that I think about it, I shoulda checked to see if there was a option to mute him. Doubt it.Anyways, IN TERMS OF AESTHETICISM  the game has some kewl concepts, but aside from the kewlness value of piggy backing onto other things that do a "void" concept with more success (lovecraft, D&D...uh, any other horror or fantasy game with "cultists" in it) that's about all the game has going for it. It reminded me of Party of Sin in terms of stale-ness. Then again, it DOES manage to incorporate game mechanics better than Party of Sin in admittedly sleepily easy puzzles to solve. But while we're on the topic, without spoliers (idk why I'm avoiding spoilers, there's nothing to spoil anyways) I did play the game through to the end with a pessimistic curiosity to see if the story would go anywhere, but...well...it's about as deep as The Grinch. Original, not Jim Carey version. There was not much to that ending. I would have been disappointed if I wasn't just so glad to finally finish the damn thing so I can delete my files and transfer it to my "Uninstall Hell" tab in my library.IN TERMS OF GAMEPLAY: At the beginning of the second level, I realized that this game not only had a narrator constantly jibber jabbering almost SOLELY to "fill a void" as it were [heeheeheehee*snort*], but that the gameplay was going to be extremely formulaic. Namely: 1) FIND FLOWER 2) TRY OUT POWER [three: we just gotta, like...become one with nature, mee-unn] REAL3)BACK TRACK SHORT DISTANCE 4) LEARN 2 OR 3 THINGS POWER CAN DO 5) RUN [AKA walk] FROM VOID. There are five (if you don't count the void) levels and they are almost exactly the same except for the new power added each level and...I guess volcano had rising lava and darkness in it. Now that I think about it, the whole game felt almost like a tutorial of itself. They held my hand so firmly that it's all sweaty and gross now. Eeeugh. The ONLY reason I didn't permanently scrap this game after the first five minutes of the second level was because I still had cards to drop and by the time I got to volcano I figured I might as well see if the ending was any good since I'd gotten this far (It wasn't. See above.)I have not played the after story puzzles, which based on accidentally clicking the first one I imagine may actually be challenging, but...I'm done. I'm done with this game. I beat the story. I put in my two hours and am thoroughly dissatisfied enough to never play again.I'm not a pro gamer by any means, but story mode was easy. Very easy. And given how shallow the plot is I think if I were to recommend a target audience for this game I would suggest...middle skoolers. Or anyone who just wants to play a spooky shadow guy in a video game more than anything else. To anyone potentially interested I STRONGLY recommend maybe watching a stream or something before buying this to see if the narrator irks you as much as he did me or if the repetitive gameplay still looks fun enough that you'd still want to rinse and repeat for two hours.

number of helpful: 8 of 12 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2014
												I. Love. This. Game.I am one of those people that really loves the narration.  It reminds me of Portal mixed with this cool flash animation I once played.  The artwork is awesome, and I love the color scheme.  It was a lot of fun to play.Now for a more in-depth review:Main Story: This is a really nice indie puzzle game, and the feel is similar to Portal.  The concept of the colors is nice, but it does get repetitive the further you get into the game.  Accept that you'll die a few times on some of the levels because you won't be prepared for what's coming.  The puzzles are simple, though.  If anything, play through the entire main story.  It's short and worth trying.  Void Mode: Void mode is hard!  I'll give them that.  It's a nice challenge, but at times, it seems to be a little too difficult.  You have to have the timing just right to get through the levels.  As void mode goes on, you'll notice that some levels are super difficult and some are super easy.  It feels like the developers might have been running out of ideas as it goes on (or just gave up - the cave levels on void mode are super easy).  I got through the entire thing without help, so it's doable.  Just accept that you'll die many, many, many times to get through it.Secret Language: If you get to this point, it is worth playing through the main storyline in the secret language.  It appears just to be the developer's rant mode.  Some of it is really stupid, but some of it is really funny...especially the end.  The one thing I didn't like is that they assumed that you are most likely a guy playing.  Ummmm...no.  I find that slightly offensive since I'm a girl and a gamer.Achievements: They are super reasonable and at just the right difficulty.  I'll admit I did look up which level the Easter egg was hidden (though I didn't look up where in the level).  I would have eventually found it if I replayed the entire game again to look for it.  I saved that achievement for last (after already having played the game through three times), and I was being lazy.  Overall, I would highly recommend this game.  I don't think it's for everyone, but it is a fun way to pass the time.  Yes, it's worth the cost with or without a sale.  :)

content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												Nihilumbra seems to be automatically compared to LIMBO by those who have played both, and rightly so as they are quite similar. However, where LIMBO is dark, eerie and gorgeously gothic, Nihilumbra revels in the atmospheric use of colour and an inventive, immersive style of puzzle-based challenges. The idea is to find and use "colours" to change your environment to allow you to move through it in different ways, overcome obstacles and defeat enemies. The visuals are stunning, with an oil-painting feel and beautiful rendering. The captions and voice-over in story mode are beautifully done and almost reminiscent of being read a story from a picture book, but with deep meaning-of-life type of stuff going on. I almost felt the need to take constant screen shots to capture the beauty of the "pages"! Moreover, for those looking for a real challenge, the Void Mode that comes after the main story line will make you weep blood - the puzzles require a serious amount of thought (one of the achievements is to die 10 times in a row on Void Mode, which I achieved with depressing ease and totally unintentionally on my first attempt at the first level!) but that just makes it all the more rewarding when you finally find the solution. I bought this game on a bit of a whim and I'm so glad I did, I love it.  I think the metascore is a little on the low side; this is a wonderful, beautiful and challenging little platform game that I recommend to everyone.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												I think Nihilumbra kinda went under the radar for pretty much anyone or maybe I wasn't paying enough attention to the news. Nihilumbra is a puzzle platformer with a very unique looking to it, you start the game being born in The Void and after you escape you end up on a strange world where The Void sends his creatures and it's coming to get you. The plot of this game along with a mindblowing soundtrack is what make them one of the best puzzle platformers of this year. According to the narrator, which identity remains a secret, The Void is one and you can't simply escape the void, he needs you in order to become one and that's why he's after you. [MIGHT CONTAIN SPOILERS FROM NOW ON] Your journey is divided in various environments ,you'll  travel to cold montains, a desert, a forest, volcanic fields and a city. Each of this places will great you an unique power which comes into place in the form of a colour and you can use them by clicking and dragging the mouse cursor on any surface, the montains grant you the blue colour which when used on any surface will make that surface slippery which will alow you to run or slide faster, the forest will grant you the green colour which if you jump on it it grants you a huge jump boost and sometimes is used for changing enemy projectiles course, in the desert you'll gain access to the brown colour which will grant you the power to slow things down or making you walk stealthly and even get enemies trapped in corners, the volcanic fields of course will grant you the red colour which when an enemy steps on it (including yourself) it will start burning and this is the first time you can actually kill an enemy by yourself and last but by no means least, the city which takes a huge role on the story grants you the colour yellow which represents electricity. During your journey you'll not only use the last power you've earned but you'll also need to remember what you've learned before. When you step into the Cold Montains you feel that you're in a different place from the void, it's cold. When you go into the forest you'll start to notice that everything in it is alive, the trees, the plants, and that starts to make you feel alive in some way, because before you were nothing, you were void. When you go to the Desert you immediately notice it's warmer there than the previous two locations and you start to wonder if you're actually starting to have "something" inside of you. After that comes the volcanic fields in which you feel it's even hotter than the desert and you realize your journey started cold, then warm and now hot and that someone makes you think that you're actually becoming "something". And last, the city, which was once inhabited by someone, there you'll start wondering if those people were actually the ones that doomed this world and not yourself, since the void has been consuming everything while it's after you, the forest, the montains, the volcanos, the desert, everything. And so you realize that youre death is inevitable, it wouldn't matter if you kept running, even though you wanted to be alive, there's no life without death and so you let yourself be consumed by the void but... the void rejects you because throughtout your journey you've consumed the colours and each one of the elements and you've become alive, "the void is nothing and there's nothing in you". And so you become free... but the game doesn't end here. After this end you'll unlock "The Void Mode" which is basicly you fighting off the void that has consumed the world in order to clean your conscience. Nihilumbra is certainly not a game for everyone, but if you enjoy a great story, very emotional and meaningful then my friend, this game is certainly for you. One of the best indie puzzler platformers I've ever played. I recommend it 100%, please buy it because I don't think it got the attention it deserved.

ScenicBorn is a creature formed by The Void (AKA nothingness) which slowly apprehends the aspects of its world carried by the natural flow.The feelings and changes it experiences are very human, so you can easily relate to it. Of short duration, with an easy gameplay - from time to time you may have to think and act quickly.Nevertheless being nihilistic, the graphics and background music create a perfect mix for a really cute relaxing game.Personally, I didn't think about my inner self while playing this game; I was peacefully exploring the world of Born, while making empathy. The atmosphere is really nice and permits you to enter smoothly the surreal, yet so familiar, world of Nihilumbra.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2014
												Nihilumbra is a puzzle platformer in which you play a scarecrow-like character that is formed from The Void. As you progress, you learn to paint different colours which you can use to manipulate the world and escape from/kill enemies. For example, paint a wall brown and you can stick to it, paint a floor red and things on top of it will be set on fire.  I bought this game because it looked kinda similarish to LIMBO (which I thought was great), but any likeness really ends with the main character being a silhouette. The puzzles in Nihilumbra are generally quite easy (granted I haven't played it in Void Mode yet, which is unlocked after you beat the main game, and looks more difficult), which, depending on your POV, may be a selling point or a negative.  Beyond the level of difficulty, the game is set up to work against frustration, with frequent checkpoints and hints.  The art appears a bit rushed in some areas (some backgrounds are pretty blurry), but is solid enough, and conveys the atmosphere of the game. The Art Gallery, which you unlock as you progress through the game, is a nice feature--I found the development character sketches cool to look at.The main problem I had with this game is the narrative: the heavy-handed narrator talks on nearly every screen, beating you over the head with the meaning behind the game, explaining what to do next, describing things you JUST did, repeating the same things over and over. A game in which you play someone discovering the world should have... well, more of a sense of discovery, rather than someone telling you what's what. At one point the narrator says "you are not a child anymore. You can do things on your own" and I was "YES! Now he'll leave me alone!", but alas no, he was back on the next screen. If you can ignore the narrator and are looking for a easy puzzler in which you can make steady progress, Nihilumbra is a fine game.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2013
												Nihilumbra is a game's name I cannot pronounce, but Nil is nothing and Umbra means Shadow, so you are Nothing's Shadow.  You are born of the void and manage to escape nothingness to a stark world.  But freedom comes at a high price as the void refuses to let you go, as you are apart of it.  Thus you condemn the world around you as you continue to escape the void as it swallows up where you have been.  Color is your weapon and tool, color is used to paint the landscape around you for an advantage of some kind.  Every panel seems to have a new bit of nerration to it.  This game is a must have and is up there with Bastion and Dust in my opinion.  Please buy it!

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												Overall, I neither hated nor loved Nihilumbra.  If there was a "Meh" recommendation option, I'd pick that.The first half of the game is enjoyable, which I think most of the reviewers agree on, based on their play times.  The story is interesting and the mechanics are fun and easy to grasp.  8 fairly short levels in each of 5 areas, with a new color/ability found in each area.  There's nothing terribly unique or groundbreaking in the game, but it's 5-10 hours of fun if you just play through the storyline.On the other hand, the void mode -- which is unlocked after completing the storyline -- is aggravating.  I understand that it's meant to be challenging, but most of the challenge comes not from the puzzles or mechanics, but from the interface.  My main complaint with this part of the game is with the "window" effect -- instead of a smooth side-scroller, we get a series of screens which are mostly independent of each other, puzzle-wise.  Not a big deal until your screen/window resolution actually impacts where this transition occurs.  Too high a resolution, and critters from the next screen react to your presence.  Too low and you may not see a trap before it's too late.  Not to mention there are a few places where you'll want to sit near the edge of that transition area for at least a few seconds to size-up the next screen (I found 1600x1024 to be fairly good for most levels).With that said, the difficulty also varies wildly, and doesn't present a smooth ramp-up as you progress.  Some late-game levels are easily completable in a few minutes or less, while some mid-game levels requirie multiple retries due to timing/strategy (I'm looking at you, volcano area).If you can pick this up for under $5 and like a side-scrolling platformer, then definitely get it.  Otherwise, there are probably better games that deserve your time.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2014
												Ugh, I hate this. I wouldn't say this game is recommendable, but at the same time, I can see why people like it. So, just read this review instead of simply looking at the thumbs up-icon to the right.Pros:1. It has a nice soundtrack. It can get repetitive after a while, but it still manages to create the right atmosphere.2. Enjoyable artwork. Of course, that's debatable, but I enjoyed it.3. The general idea of manipulating your environment. It's nothing new, but the abilities themselves are rather cool.Cons:1. The dialogues. Seriously, can't the voice actor just shut up? The acting actually isn't the problem, that's well done. But the dialogue itself is so atrocious and annoying and pretentious. I don't need a comment on everything there's happening. The game would have been _much_ better without any dialogue at all.2. Which brings me to the next point: Too easy. The puzzles are so easy to solve because most of the time you just have to use the one ability you just acquired. Combining abilities happened very seldom and if for some reason you are stuck, the game literally forces the solution upon you through the narrator and the hints. It's a puzzle game, I want to find the solution myself.3. The length. I don't have anything against short games, but the game can be completed within less than two hours. Then of course you can beat in the hardcore mode again, but that's not the solution. They could've added more content, really.4. The controls. The character is... "wobbly". It's really difficult to land accurate jumps and even more so, when I have to do the same section all over again, because the last checkpoint was two miles away.5. The tutorials. Okay, seriously. Why do I need those? Not only do you get to know the different abilities, before you can use them, but there's plenty of opportunities to test them out in the actual levels. I don't need a tutorial that basically teaches stuff I already know.So, do I recommend the game? For a discount, yeah, why not? At full price? Rather not, no. I don't know, the game feels a bit too pretentious, like it's trying to jump on the "platformes with a deep background"-bandwagon we already know from Thomas Was Alone (which was excellent) and LIMBO (which was excellent as well).

Posted: April 27, 2014
												There is a good game in here, but to get to it you must first plow through a rather dull, ~2 hour long story mode with mostly tutorial-level challenges and a narrative that sounds like a cross between Thomas was Alone and Bastion styles of narrative but very poorly executed (read: the narration is shallow, redundant and gets unbearably annoying after the first 15 minutes). At least you can turn the narrator off.Level design also has some issues, like the irregular, "bumpy" terrain and enemies with deceptively big hitboxes. Nothing major, but these can still annoy the player from time to time.Aside from that, it's a nice puzzle platformer with some good music. Nothing too special, but by no means bad.

content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												Honestely, this game is overlooked. And it's a crime.So what IS Nihilumbra? Without Spoiling anything, its about a little blob-thing (named Born, apparently) who tries to escape from the Void and make himself exist in the world. Does he suceed? Play the game. You'll find out.Gameplay-wise, it's a simple 2D Platformer/Puzzle game, implementing the use of different elements to continue your journey. Each element helps you in one particular way (e.g. brown makes you stick to walls/ceilings, red burns enemies and boxes, and so on). The main story is fairly simple, and can be completed in about an hour and a half or so. There is a harder mode called Void mode which does present a fairly difficult challenge, but wasn't as enjoying (at least, in my opinion). Visually, it's not bad. Not the best I've ever seen, but simple enough to do the job. It reminds me of Braid at times (the "painting/storybook" look).While I think the soundtrack isn't as memorable as other indie games, it is rather relaxing and easy on the ol' ear drums. I personally love the Void chase music.This is definitely a game that you want to take your time on, not because its difficult, but just to take it all in.The price is a bit over what I would pay for this kind of game (about $4-5), but if there's a sale, don't hesitate on picking it up. You won't regret it.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2016
												Overall, I would just barely recommend this game. At this point I have only finished the story mode, I have yet to try Void mode, but I wanted to center my review on the base game first. The first three colours you receive are fun, and slightly reminiscent of Element41, which is a game I really enjoyed. But the last two seemed like they had a vision for the game based on 5 colours and no ideas left. There could also be a much easier way to switch between colours, like using the number keys or cycling through using q and e. That coupled with what I thought was really weird voiceover work (both the voice acting and the writing) were the two main flaws of the game. The voiceover sounds like the guy from truck commercials trying to sound omniscient and he just came off sounding kinda bored. What made matters worse, voiceover-wise, was the writing. I would say the writing is by far the weakest facet of the game. It's too explanatory. What makes games like Element41 great to play was the simplicity in the explanation, and they didn't overuse the voice to further the plot. Nihilumbra felt the need to explain every metaphor to death and back. Now for the positives:The level design was interesting, especially towards the end where there could have been a few different ways to use the colours to move ahead in the level. The atmosphere is very neat, and the creatures from the void had some cool designs. All in all, I don't regret buying this game on sale for $2.39, I'm not sure I would pay the full $7.99 list price for it as a relatively poor person. Get it on sale if you can, see if you like it.

content:
Posted: May 19, 2015
												A true work of art. This puzzle platformer has a unique brush mechanic that allows for many ways to overcome obstacles that nicely complements the whimsical art style. It'll run on anything, and still look amazing. The story is very thoughtful and takes a little over 2.5 hours. There is a challenge mode called Void Mode for when you finish the story, and it is very difficult, so there is a lot of content here. Overall it's a unique take on the PC puzzle game with something for everyone.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 29, 2015
												I picked this up during a Humble Bundle sale having never heard of it. I didn't know what to expect and really wasn't expecting much. To my surprise, Nihilumbra delivered and turned out to be one of the best and most underrated indie games I've ever played.Story:You are Born. Born was created from The Void but has somehow separated from it and is now in the world. However, The Void will not allow this and is now chasing Born in an attempt to suck him back into the darkness. In order for Born to escape The Void, he must allow everything else in his path be destroyed.Gameplay:Nihilumbra is a puzzle-platformer. As you progress through the game, Born will be granted new colors, which the player can use to paint the terrain in order to solve puzzles and aid him in his platforming. In total there are five different colors. Each have a different use and create a different effect. Throughout the game, Born will be accompanied by a narrator that will talk to him. It is uknown exactly who this narrator is whether he be Born, The Void or something else. The narrator really gives this game it's charm and gives insight to the world and what is going on. Sometimes he says some really philosophical things and it really adds to the atmosphere. Speaking of that, the atmosphere is amazing. The combination of colors, textures, music and narration sets a very solemn, yet relaxing mood. The main part of the game is very short. It only took me about 4 hours to complete. However, once you complete it, you'll unlock “Void Mode” which is essentially hard mode. Void Mode offers the same levels but with different and much harder puzzles.Conclusion:Overall, I'd recommend this to anyone that's a fan of platformers or puzzle-platformers. It's really unique and highly underrated. Nihilumbra is a very insightful, relaxing and fun experience. That's what this game is. It's more than just a game. It's an experience to be had.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18, 2014
												Nihilumbra is both a very interesting and very divided game. It was presented to me as "Limbo meets Portal," but in practice, I found it to be like neither of these things. The unfitting dark creatures roaming about the relatively normal environments felt more like Heart of Darkness, and the emphasis on the "paint mechanic" (there are no portals) gives it more similarities to Tag: The Power of Paint. I was also told that the game made figurative waves on the iOS market, but that is a market so inundated with inane and uninteresting nonsense that the comment meant exactly nothing to me, so I went about my playthrough of Nihilumbra determined not to give it a free pass for standing out from mediocrity. So let's get to it.I said that I felt that the game was divided. The gameplay is divided into two distinct modes, the story mode, and the void mode. The latter is unlocked after completing the former. The story mode is what you'd expect; it tells the story. The biggest problem people will have with the story mode is the narrator, or more specifically, the narration design. The decision to have a narrator in a game about nihilism is questionable. I'd think silent, empty text would serve the presentation much better, so that's what I went with when I played it. I don't think the voice is necessarily terrible, but I don't think the presence of a voice in this game is necessarily warranted, either. The narration is also triggered by your position on the different screens within the levels, and if you die and return to a checkpoint, the narration will repeat every time, and this can get grating. Fortunately, for the people who will be too lazy to mute the narration, the story mode is almost too easy.Void mode is the game's answer to that. It's the obligatory, "you can't spell 'indie' without 'die'" departure from the almost insultingly easy story mode. This section of the game is of a very much "Oddworldian" difficulty. There is plenty of trial and error to go with the more challenging puzzles. You will die in void mode. I've seen void mode criticized a lot, but again, these are (mostly) iPad gamers we're talking about. Fortunately, you are given a reprieve from the narration, but this can be both good and bad. You are introduced to void mode with the promise of closure to the game's somewhat bitter epilogue (What? Did you expect a good ending in a game about nihilism? DID YOU?). While you do technically get that closure, it's accompanied with absolutely no narration or text, so it's a bit of a dull reward for anyone who played through void mode because they liked the story and wanted that elusive happy ending. The only other thing you get (besides the achievements and accompanying bragging rights) is a "secret language," which changes the text of the narration and makes it the complete antithesis of taking itself seriously, so if you thought the story was pretentious garbage, hated it and want some cheap catharsis, you might enjoy replaying story mode for that, but it will just end up leaving a bad taste in everyone else's mouths, especially with the internet memes which have basically already made the "humor" rather dated.There is appeal to be had in both the story mode and the void mode, but I think the whole package kind of antagonizes itself. I don't see many people enjoying the whole of the game. Most people will probably heavily prefer one half over the other, and people who prefer the story mode will have to settle with the bitter ending, and people who prefer void mode will have to trudge through the story mode. Whether you decide this game is worth it to you or not will depend on which of those two types of people you decide you are, and whether you feel that you'll only enjoy one half of the game.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 7, 2015
												I feel that a forewarning before you begin playing is required.. When it comes down to it, due to how the game is laid out, it makes it like the narrator through the game is speaking to you, portrayed as your cute blobby character within the game. It's quite harsh and for anyone with a low self esteem, it can really be deterring to play, it was for me at quite a few points, too. Something of which I don't believe was thought through very thoroughly. It however evolves as your character does within each stage of the game. With that been said, let us continue!The only thing I can draw a comparison to is perhaps Limbo, Portal, Oddworld: Abe’s Oddysee, Abyss Odyssey and partially Contrast.Now, starting with a basic breakdown, you are part of the void (basically your replacement to being in a womb) a place of darkness and decay, and are born to be a little shapeless voidling.. You want to explore and be part of something bigger than yourself. Typically you let that take over and begin a journey that pulls you away from the void, however, this does not please the void as one does not simply leave it.You begin by taking a human like shape, to feel as though you fit in the human world easier, while the voice continues to tell you that you are stupidly deluding yourself for trying to think that you could do such a thing. You ignore it and continue on through little puzzles along the way, and the further you go through, the more you learn about yourself and the world around you. The first ability you get is a blue goop, basically an icy slide (hence the little comparison to Portal I was half expecting the next one to be orange), anywho, this aids you to get through the next few levels of puzzles and annoying timing levels however the puzzles themselves are well thought out for the most part, and give you a decent sense of satisfaction and relief when you figure them out. You continue on to discover 5 other colors, all of which provides you something new to help you through each of the changing environments tailored to each color, (blue-ice, green-forest, brown-desert, red-volcanic, yellow-electricity, purple-void).However, the fact that the void is closely following to recapture you means everything in it's path is destroyed. The world your voidling blob has come to love is being destroyed due to them being frivolous, leaving your character feeling responsible. Final summation; in all, it's a really well put together puzzle/platformer. The scenery is gorgeous but can sometimes be a little repetitive. Music fits in amazingly with the atmosphere being slightly abrasive yet quite immersive, puzzles are escalated in difficulty slightly too quickly with it going from casual to incredibly complicated and requiring a need to have mastered all the colors you've been given, and lastly the initially discouraging narrator. All in all though, it's a worthwhile experience to play through and on completion, it gives you even more reply value, having to fix what you've destroyed.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2016
												Overall, I would just barely recommend this game. At this point I have only finished the story mode, I have yet to try Void mode, but I wanted to center my review on the base game first. The first three colours you receive are fun, and slightly reminiscent of Element41, which is a game I really enjoyed. But the last two seemed like they had a vision for the game based on 5 colours and no ideas left. There could also be a much easier way to switch between colours, like using the number keys or cycling through using q and e. That coupled with what I thought was really weird voiceover work (both the voice acting and the writing) were the two main flaws of the game. The voiceover sounds like the guy from truck commercials trying to sound omniscient and he just came off sounding kinda bored. What made matters worse, voiceover-wise, was the writing. I would say the writing is by far the weakest facet of the game. It's too explanatory. What makes games like Element41 great to play was the simplicity in the explanation, and they didn't overuse the voice to further the plot. Nihilumbra felt the need to explain every metaphor to death and back. Now for the positives:The level design was interesting, especially towards the end where there could have been a few different ways to use the colours to move ahead in the level. The atmosphere is very neat, and the creatures from the void had some cool designs. All in all, I don't regret buying this game on sale for $2.39, I'm not sure I would pay the full $7.99 list price for it as a relatively poor person. Get it on sale if you can, see if you like it.

content:
Posted: January 27
												You are the void, created by the void itself, and your purpose is to outrun a ghastly purple entity. You'll be traversing different landscapes along the way, as the title attempts to relay a message that's moving at times, and touches upon the idea of destruction as a means to survive.Gameplay-wise, the release is fairly simple. It's a standard 2D platformer with a twist, which arrives in the form of colour-based powers. Along your sombre journey, you'll encounter flowers, which provide you with unique abilities. You'll start out slow, frail, and unable to attack enemies, but as you soak up these vibrant skills, you'll find yourself able to bounce off the floor, slide on ice, and much more.Nihilumbra is not the biggest game, but sometimes great things come in small packages. The puzzles are not especially difficult, but there's a nice plot and some decent presentation here which will push you through to its conclusion. If you're looking for something a little different for your Vita, then make sure that you don't a-void this one.
