content:
Posted: November 19, 2015
												  Nihilumbra is, overall, a great experience. A platformer somewhere along the lines of Limbo, it's less atmoshperic, but its thought-provoking premisis, coupled with some intelligently designed platforming and puzzles, make it a real gem of the genre.  The game's short but thoughtful philosophical interludes are perfectly fitted within the environments that the game has you explore, and it succesfully conveys the feeling of a journey toward maturity, gradually finding out more about the world as it is and what you can (or can't) have an impact on. The narrator's remarks are frequent but never too revealing, thus leaving you the liberty to link and interprete the metaphors for yourself.   Nihilumbra also gradually opens up its gameplay through the aquisition of colours, with which you can change the environment. One lets you create ice, which helps you traverse certain sections more quickly, or enables you to make certain objects or enemies slide and fall, given that there is an initial momentum to begin with. Another is mud, which acts both as a means of slowing down - yourself and others -, stealthily traversing a section, as well as a sticky surface, allowing you to stick to walls or ceilings. Each of the six colours has its unique multiple purposes. The great thing about this is that most puzzles or obstacles you encounter along the way have multiple solutions, so you can do it your own way.  The aesthetics are very well designed - the diverse environments look beautiful, yet not majestic. The music used is very suitable as well, and nicely adapted to each of the worlds you explore. However, I think it's used in excess. Sure, since it's not trying to convey an atmosphere as tense and empty as Limbo's , I wouldn't have pleaded for complete silence, but there are some sections of the game which would have benefitted from less rather than more background noise.   While the main story mode is rather easy, and can be completed in around 3 hours, the real challenge here is represented by Void mode. It's a redesign of the original maps, but made much much much harder. So hard that I think the contrast between the main game, where I was never stuck for more than 2-3 minutes, and Void mode, where simply the first level of the first chapter took me around 20 minutes to complete, is a bit sharp.   Overall, I can only tell you to buy this game. It's fairly priced for the content it offers, it will delight you with its beautiful visuals and smart story analogies.

number of helpful: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 12, 2014
												Nihilumbra is a really hard game to review because it's almost impossible to describe properly.You play as Born, a being that emerges from the Void & takes on a humanoid shape. You explore the world, gaining colours, each with an ability to help you progress. You 'paint' them onto a surface to activate that ability, whether it's making the surface slippery, sticky, burning hot, bouncy or conductive. You then use these colours to solve puzzles, defeat Void monsters & escape the Void as it hunts you across the side-scroller world.Sounds a bit plain & simple, but it is actually a fabulous little game. The graphics are perfectly judged; pretty but simple, not overblown for a side-scroller. The music is as good as it gets, varied & often haunting & eerie.The greatest part is the narration. It's not constant, but what there is, is a real asset to the game. I could never quite tell if it was Born's own voice berrating & encouraging him to resist & fight to exist, an external voice talking to Born, or simply a narrator talking to the player. The narration is presented in what can best be described as a moving picture-book, with the words that are being spoken appearing prominently on the screen in large text. You are able to play without stopping to wait for the text to fade though, which shows sensible design.The puzzles are challenging, generally requiring you to make use of the newest colour, but always you have to think about all of them throughout. Even the length is perfectly balanced, with a 2nd play through built in if you haven't had enough, but doesn't necessarily add to the story.In fact, I'm struggling to think of much that's wrong with Nihilumbra, aside from the fact that it is a very quirky game that won't appeal to everyone. At a stretch, it's not the ultimate in immersion, but given that Nihilumbra's main plot is only a few hours long, it doesn't need to be. Everything about it feels complete, a game that has fulfilled it's entire starting breif.If you are interested in a well-rounded, well though-out & beautifully scripted game that is something totally different, then you will almost certainly get something out of Nihilumbra. I'm really pleased to be able to say I own & have played Nihilumbra.

number of helpful: 12 of 22 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 20, 2016
												The mechanics are interesting and fairly well implemented, the graphics and music are forgettable yet passable, but the narration destroys this game. Firstly, the narrator is ever present, and rather than relaying a plot through environmental storytelling or immediate presentation, Nihilumbra consistently relies on the narrator's explicit descriptions. Second, the writing is extremely cheesy, constantly explicating and repeating how the protagonist, addressed in second person, is supposedly feeling as well as the considerations the game wants the player to make about the protagonist's relationship with and impact on the world. Mechanically, most puzzles are extremely easy, many solutions are given away immediately and explicitly by the narrator, and the same dynamics act as solutions to many, even subsequent, puzzles, making the levels feel like flavored repetitions of the same scenarios with no new challenge. New mechanics and dynamics are not explained through level design but rather explicated by the narrator, and the level design itself is not particularly clever although this is mostly insignificant due to the omnipresence of the guiding narration. In short, the awkward narrative explication of story, mechanics, dynamics, and solutions combined with repetitive puzzles and resulting low difficulty overwhelms the otherwise interesting mechanical potential and renders Nihilumbra a rather uninteresting game.

Posted: November 24, 2015
												This is a pretty neat puzzler-platformer, with gorgeous art and cool music. In Story mode, the game is easy, but the main point of it is for you to enjoy the game, admire it's landscapes, relax, listen to the narrator, and getting familiar with the game mechanics. Once you finish it (2-3 hours) you'll unlock the Void mode, and here is where the real game begins, with plenty of puzzles and challenges for you to complete. Sometimes is hard, but never overwhelming. And the difficulty is evenly spread through the levels, so all 5 worlds have roughly the same difficulty. If you beat it, there's a cool bonus that gives incentive to replay the Story mode. In the end, this is a nice cohesive game, with good gameplay.

Posted: December 30, 2013
												As a big fan of 2D sidescrolling puzzle platformers, Nihilumbra gave me exactly what I wanted while also bringing in a fresh perspective. You play as Born, a creature that was created in the Void, and you are trying to outrun your fate while discovering the new world you are in. You learn to use elements of the world to your advantage, by finding colors and 'painting' (or erasing) those elements onto the world around you. You can make yourself slide, bounce, etc. You can also use those elements to make OTHER things in the world slide, bounce, and so on. This becomes fun pretty fast, and satisfying as well. The satisfaction I used to feel after making something blow up in Oddworld is the same satisfaction I feel when I make a monster slide off a platform or I successfully rebound a bullet off of a few walls to thwart my enemy. Most of the levels can be taken at your own pace, and offer fair, regularly placed checkpoints to assistant you in advancing. There are a few, but still fair, timed levels, where the Void chases you. There are checkpoints during these levels as well, and though I normally hate timed levels in platformers, these are made to be player-friendly. Though there is a lot of dialog from the narrator, it's spoken as you move, so you don't have to stop for it. So far the levels have been increasing slowly in difficulty, allowing the player to adjust as they continue.I think this is a great game for any for any fans of puzzle platformers. It has the feeling of being detailed, unique, and well thought out, though it's easy to toggle through your colors/elements with a click of the mouse, so it's also nice that it's far easier to control than some other games I've come across.

Posted: January 1, 2014
												Nihilumbra is one of the few games I've played so far that I'm sure will reserve a special spot in my memory. Right from the beginning, the story captivated me to the point that I just kept playing until the end, without even stopping once. The main game is only a few hours long (~3, I'd say), but once you've completed it, you'll gain access to "Void mode", which is basically "Hardcore mode". It's tough, to say the least, but rewarding.As far as Indie games go, this is the perfect example of how it should be done: Unique, fun to play, beautiful to both look at and listen to, but all without a huge budget.

Posted: June 28, 2014
												This game was a somewhat odd puzzle-platformer. The storyline was interesting and somewhat moving, and the mechanic of adding colors to change the environment was novel. The first round of puzzles weren't too challenging and most people could solve without too much difficultly (without a guide). The second playthrough (or void mode) becomes much more challenging and much more fun in my opinion. I almost wish that it had been the game all along rather than the second playthrough because it has much more creative puzzles. Unfortunately the second playthough drops the narrator and doesn't seem to have any story to go with it, other than here are some more puzzles for you to do. So overall 8/10 game. Fun story without too much depth, fun mechanics, good gameplay, but some questionable decision about why they made the second playthrough drop the continued narrative.

PROS:+ fun gameplay+ nice UI & menu+ great puzzles+ challenging void mode+ pretty visuals & in-game art book+ decent narrative & storyCONS:- a couple of ridiculously hard puzzles- rather short main story- void mode does not have narrativeComment:This game went on sale so I picked it up because I am a fan of indie games and it had a good rating. So it is a platformer puzzle game with a decent narrative (in story mode). I was not sure if I like it at first, it was okay but frankly it felt too easy once you got the hang of the various colors/skills. Well, until I beat the main game and went into void mode. While some puzzles had me guessing right away what I am supposed to do there were MANY that I went dozens of times because I had no clue and I always died before I figured it out. However after beating the void mode levels you do feel a sense of accomplishment and the checkpoint system is rather fair. So I like even void mode after some consideration since it made me very angry but because I sucked at it, not because it was truly bad. Overall this is a nice game and, even though short, it is quite fun. Recommended!

Posted: February 20, 2016
												Nihlumbra is true to its name: a game about Nihilism and a little umbral shadow that escapes from the nothingness and wants to LIVE! It’s all about trying to escape your fate, and seems like it’ll end with the typical Nihilist “everything is meaningless and hopeless” but you’ll be pleasantly surprised. You control a little shadow who learns about colors, each of which has a different effect: Blueish-white = ice, Green = trampoline, red = fire, brown = sticky, yellow = electricity. You combine these skills as you go along to solve puzzles and try to escape your fate.Let me preface my review by saying that a lot of the negative reviews are unfair. One of the main criticisms of this game is that the main story is easy, and the so-called afterparty known as “Void Mode” is insanely hard. That’s because they’re thinking of it as one continous game, when it’s not. It’s essentially a “Story mode” where you learn the skills, do some levels of varying difficulty (usually easy to medium), you enjoy an interesting story in an interesting world as you go along. It ends with the words “The End.” You can play to this point and have a wonderful experience, perhaps not one that’s 100% worth the $7.99 asking price, but almost certainly worth $5 and DEFINITELY worth the $1.99 I paid for it on sale. If you’re a hardcore puzzler, then you get BONUS levels with some added difficulty. Yes, the bonus levels are GRUELING, with some colors (i.e. powers) forbidden in certain areas, few (if any) save points, and really tricky timing at times. (Like starting off a level with something directly behind you and chasing you.) To be honest, I played a few levels of the Void Mode and felt a little cheated, because I looked at a level and said “Oh, I know what to do! The story mode taught me this! Oh, wait…I can’t use fire here. Or ice. I have no effin’ clue how to get past these 6 enemies without dying over and over.” A lot of them weren’t about planning or skill, mostly about finding the ONE solution that was correct, whereas the main game allowed some creative thinking and was forgiving with your various options. Each “world” of levels ends with a “You’re being chased by the Void, so solve these puzzles really quickly” which is frustrating at times, but it’s kind of like the Boss battle of each world, so it works, and it’s a nice change of pace I guess.Pros:+Great music!+Great art – complex yet minimalist+Interesting game mechanic with tons of cool powers to mix and match+Atmospheric – Each area of the world reflects the color you’ve just learned. E.g. You learn red in a volcano level with steam and lava. You learn the blue/white color in an ice world with howling wild and falling snow.Neutral:~ Voice acting is AWFUL, but I put it in neutral because there’s an option to turn it off. It seems unnecessary anyway, because all the words are on the screen, and the voice ruins the atmosphere by interjecting itself all the time. I turned it off after a few levels.~ I’m not a fan of the end-of-the-set-of-levels chase scene, but some people might appreciate the change of pace, so I’ll put this here.Cons:- As mentioned above, your experience will either be A) very short if you only play through the story, but will be casual and enjoyable or B) long and grueling, if you play Void Mode. So it’s either a length problem or a difficulty problem, but not actually both. Paradox.Overall: 8.5/10Story Mode: 9/10. Fun, casual, but not overly challenging.Void mode: 4/10. Punishing. Not for the faint of heart. Skippable.Tl;dr version: Buy it, if only for the story mode.

Posted: November 19, 2014
												Indie games always tend to be either hit or miss, but after playing Nihilumbra for quite a bit, I can safely say that the creators certainly hit the mark on this one. I definitely enjoyed the art style and idea of the story, a creature born from the nothingness of the world, seeking a purpose in a world in which it doesn't belong. While a puzzle/platformer with a nice challenge in it's own way, I find that between the story, art style, narration, and the way the whole thing ties together, makes it a beautiful piece of work that can certainly hold well in the argument of whether or not games can be viewed as art.

Posted: May 6, 2015
												This was a fun little game. Nihilumbra is a 2D platformer that focuses on puzzle solving and spans 5 main areas, each of which consists of several stages. Each area introduces a new colour, which then becomes important for the solutions of puzzles in that area. For example, blue colour makes you slide along as though on ice, making you travel faster and jump further, green makes you bounce, brown makes you stick to walls, and so on.I found the use of unique effects of each colour for puzzle solving to be a pretty cool mechanic that made puzzles interesting. Some colours even had multiple uses. For example, the red could burn the enemies, but it could also make fireflies glow brighter, hence illuminating darker areas.The overall execution is very nice. The art and the music are especially stunning. Though the narrator's voice was a bit offputting at times and seemed a tad repetitive. Worse yet, if you died and returned to a checkpoint, the narrator would say the same quote again, even if he already said it earlier. And having to redo the puzzles you've done already just to get to the one you died on was also frustrating.The game in general is worth playing if you like puzzle games, though the story mode is pretty short (took me about 3 hours to complete). After the story mode, you unlock the void mode, which is significantly harder and might not be for everyone, as you go through the same areas except with much more complex puzzles and more enemies, often pitting you in very vulnerable situations where you're bound to fail or die dozens of times before you succeed. So if you're on the fence and unsure, best to get the game when it's on sale. The story mode is worth it alone.I would certainly like to see more similar games from the developers, because this one definitely had the right idea.

Posted: June 15, 2015
												  The game runs very smoothly, and the graphics are absolutely fantastic. It is actually very easy to play, and it's not extremely stressful like a lot of other platformers. The story in Nihilumbra is of those you'd never expect to find in a platformer such as this one.  I have seen complaints about the controls, where you've had to click the bubble to used your Void "color." This is, infact, one way of doing it. If you're on the Desert stage, and you already don't know that holding down the right mouse-button would let you use your Void "color," you may need to re-check your controls to make sure that you know what each one does.   As for the story of the game, it's wonderful. Tell me, how often do you find a platformer game with as much story as this one has? Yes, it's a little bit odd, I agree; just the fact that there IS a story to this game at all is what makes it so great.  Now for the narrating. I really adore the deep voice, but sometimes the narrator is only pointing out the obvious. For example, when you first ecounter the Kilmeth, he tells you that it can "erase colors" after you've most likely figured that out [if] you'd tried to burn it. As you progress through the game, he's only telling you things that have already figured out. I will agree that you could just turn off the voice, but what's the point when the text would still be there? It's what he's saying that's the most obnoxious, not the voice (for me, at least).           +Swift

Posted: December 30, 2013
												As a big fan of 2D sidescrolling puzzle platformers, Nihilumbra gave me exactly what I wanted while also bringing in a fresh perspective. You play as Born, a creature that was created in the Void, and you are trying to outrun your fate while discovering the new world you are in. You learn to use elements of the world to your advantage, by finding colors and 'painting' (or erasing) those elements onto the world around you. You can make yourself slide, bounce, etc. You can also use those elements to make OTHER things in the world slide, bounce, and so on. This becomes fun pretty fast, and satisfying as well. The satisfaction I used to feel after making something blow up in Oddworld is the same satisfaction I feel when I make a monster slide off a platform or I successfully rebound a bullet off of a few walls to thwart my enemy. Most of the levels can be taken at your own pace, and offer fair, regularly placed checkpoints to assistant you in advancing. There are a few, but still fair, timed levels, where the Void chases you. There are checkpoints during these levels as well, and though I normally hate timed levels in platformers, these are made to be player-friendly. Though there is a lot of dialog from the narrator, it's spoken as you move, so you don't have to stop for it. So far the levels have been increasing slowly in difficulty, allowing the player to adjust as they continue.I think this is a great game for any for any fans of puzzle platformers. It has the feeling of being detailed, unique, and well thought out, though it's easy to toggle through your colors/elements with a click of the mouse, so it's also nice that it's far easier to control than some other games I've come across.

Posted: July 20, 2015
												This game is awesome. Though I got it on sale for 1.99, It's surely worth the full 7.99. The game isn't very long. But also not to short. After the credits scene, it unlocks alot more levels, but I havn't gotten to those yet. But it took me a good 2 .8 hours to get that far (It is a puzzle game [kinda] so playtime may vary). Anyways in the game you start out as a baby, but you were born in the void. You escape the void and go to the world. And theres snow everywhre. But you find a flower. You pick it. It gives you a color, blue. You can place and destroy that color at will. You can run fast on that color. You ue it to solve puzzles and whatnot. Then the void comes back for you. And you run, knowing that the void is destroying the world behind you. You still run. And you escape. With that world gone. Then you end up in a forest world.Play more to find all the colors, and all the worlds. And to see what happens in the end. When he can't run anymore from the void.7/10

Posted: January 7, 2015
A Paladin’s Steam Review: Nihilumbra. A Bit Pretentious and A Bit Overrated.Genre: 2D Platformer with Story. Developed & Published by: BeautiFun Games Platform: Windows, Mac, LinuxBusiness Model: Base GameCopy Purchased by Myself PreambleThis is an overrated game. As I sit here and think about my experience with this game, that is all I can think. It got a lot of fanfare when it came out in 2013 but I can’t figure out why it did. This isn't really anything new for the genre and mostly just toes the line of what's come before. Maybe that's just me. Story ThoughtsNihilumbra is a 2D puzzle platformer where you follow Born, a being that fled something called “the Void”. You journey through multiple “areas” with various puzzles to be solved. All while being narrated/told what you’re feeling the entire time. The game gives off a feeling of being pretentious, whether that was intended or not. I didn't find the story to be all that new, interesting or even good. It simply existed to talk to me about life, death and acceptance of said life. However, I feel like other games have handled it in a better, less ham-fisted way. As it is, Nihilumbra is all about that point and well, leaves a lot to be desired because of it. PlatformingThe platforming and puzzle solving itself isn’t too bad. It’s just really forgiving with the difficulty increasing slowly and steadily the entire campaign but never getting too challenging. The only challenge the game really creates is switching between the different colors/powers quickly. Outside of that, there was only one puzzle I got stuck on and that was because I didn’t realize I could use the brown color to stick to the floor while a magnet was running nearby. One puzzle out of the entire experience. Not a really good sign. PC SettingsSettings are really basic but unsurprisingly so. It has v-sync, some resolution options and that’s about it. But as its a 2D game, it doesn't really need much. So, not a big deal. Graphics are reasonably ok, though I don’t think they’re the best we’ve ever seen in this genre. Not even back in 2013. Sound is passable but there isn’t much depth to it. The soundtrack itself is overwhelming repetitive and you will quickly tire of each area’s new theme. A mute option would have been loved. Final ThoughtsI’m not sure how I missed playing this platformer when it came out nearly two years ago, during a time I was all into platformers. Playing it now, well, leaves a feeling of ”mehness” to it. Sorry, I can’t think of another word to describe this feeling and that word is certainly not useful. However, as the game works and there’s nothing inherently wrong with it (other than being overrated/pretentious), I can think of worse ways you could waste two hours of your time. But I can also think of better uses. Read this review and more on A Paladin Without A Crusade[kingisaaclinksr.com]

												Nihilumbra is alright. It's cheap enough to be easy to recommend. New game plus is frustrating at times, but it's optional. overall, it's a fun game for killing a few hours with  very little invesntment. More information is down belowThe game has issues, primarily due to it being a mobile port:   - The keys cannot be rebound, and you cannont assign custom keys to particular abilities.  - There are few options, and what options are present are icons instead of text. I had no      idea what they did.  - The controls are tempermental at times. If you use an ability too quickly, the ability will     be ineffective.  - some abilites don't look right in some situations  brown can make you stick to     nothing or inside walls if you stick at certain points . It doesn't effect gamplay     but it does look goofy.  - The new game plus mode can be frustrating. You can easily make small mistakes that      forces a reset. In particular, pushing boxes into walls will make them unmovable. if you     have no way to destroy the box, you are forced to restart. In addition, some enemy      placements feel unfair The first level in the void run is a good example. There      is an enemy immediately on screen, and you have to react fast to avoid a death.      Because you can't bind colors to keys, you have no way to quickly select a color. Most      early deaths will be because you didn't know what color is needed for the next screen. The game does have a lot going for it:   - It's cheap at all times.  - It can be finished quickly. (2 hours)  - There is a new game plus mode that adds to the run time and gives more of a challange.  - The game allows for a lot of freedom with the mechanics.  - Everything looks and sounds great.  - It is fun and satisfying to beat the levels quickly.

Posted: December 31, 2013
												Nihilumbra is, at its core, a puzzle game. You control the strange black shape (shown on majority of screenshots), and you can use 5 different colors to give surfaces certain properties (like "slippery", "sticky", "bouncy" etc.). These surfaces then affect you, enemies AND objects alike.The good thing about Nihilumbra is that you always know where to go (always to the right), so if you see two paths to the rigth (upper and lower) and one of them turns out to be blocked, there's not any real backtracking or getting lost. The game progresses very nicely.The puzzle challenges are quite good, sometimes there is some head-scratching involved until you figure out the solution. Each of the 5 worlds ends with a somewhat nerve-wrecking "boss level", where there is a time limit in the form of a big wall of destruction that is always progressing from left to right, so you will need to be able to perform the solution at reasonable speed. But the system of checkpoints is very well thought through and there is virtually no frustration - just tons of fun.Took me 2 hours to finish, and I liked every minute of it.I got the game for about 3 euros during the Community vote sale, and I would not hesitate to spend the current reduced price of 6.30. If that becomes the after-sale price in January, I strongly recommend this game.

Posted: April 21
												Nihilumbra, a game in which you play as an entity created by the void trying to come to life.  Nihil, Latin for nothing. I can quite appreciate the wordplay there i got to admit it. The story is non existent, all there is is a narrator following along. All he does is tell you what you are supposed to do basically, so the story is your journey which I will come to now. Coming to the gameplay. This honestly disappointed me quite a bit. The gameplay is composed of simple platforming gradually throwing in different abilities for your character. Nevertheless these abilities add basically nothing to the gameplay. You will encounter enemies which are nothing more than a gimmick as they don't really do too much, seeing as they can easily be taken out with aid of your abilities. The 5 different stages do very little to the gameplay as all of them introduce another ability.  The problem I have with the game is that it is basically the same thing over and over again rarely even having to use the ability you've learned previously. This bored me to the point where i didn't even feel like giving the void mode a shot There is nothing much more to say about it, other than the fact that i closed the game and won't ever open it again after finishing the main "story". I just can't wholeheartedly recommend this game

content:
Posted: September 24, 2015
												 In this game, you are being that escapes "The Void" - a place that eats it's way into anything and everything and, inside it, there's nothing. Much like black holes, really. Somehow, your escape alerts The Void and it starts chasing you. You go from being nothing, having no purpose in life, to grow intelectually through the learning of colors, an interesting mechanism that, by painting them on the game's surface, each one will provoke a different effect on it, ranging from slippery surfaces to making them burn, etc. In essence, this game is really philosophical. I thought the message embeded throughout the story was something from the likes of "You are insignificant, yes. But if you stand out, explore, make something different, you will become significant. You will become something." The narrator basically helps to tell the story, as through every section of the game, he says something. The art, background-wise, is very pretty. The models and tiles are nothing suprising, but that's not negative. There's an art gallery that will slowly unlock after the completion of each level. As for length, the game is relatively short. But, after you do complete the main story, there's a void mode to be completed, which can take more than the actually storyline, and it is freakishly hard! Also, the game's controls are smooth and easily maneuverable. Overall, I completed recommend Nihilumbra. For it's story, controls and for the originality that it takes to come up with something such as "The Void". Besides, it's cheap for what you get!Screenshot:

												I just played my first 40 or so minutes and reached the Ash Desert, which is the 3rd world after the intro section. My god is it a wonderful game!To put it in perspective: I usually, for almost every single game, play in windowed mode. So I actually went to the options menu, set the game to windowed, and started playing. Even before leaving the Void, I had already switched back to 1080p fullscreen and got rid of all external distractions to best take in the beautiful art direction, soundtrack and voice.The setting, while rather depressing in many ways, actually also feels quite uplifting - and I can appreciate that. That the gameplay is very intuitive and enjoyable only supports my belief that I've got a real gem on my hard drive right now.Thanks to the developers for Nihilumbra. How in all the hells could a game like this have been stuck in Greenlight-limbo for over a year?! Valve really need to get their act together....I will update this "review" later on, when I have played (a lot) more of it. However, I doubt this game can anything but better from there on out. It is a lovely game, and I would very much recommend picking it up!

content:
Posted: January 3
												Nihilumbra has a defined art style, strives for narrative, and deals whimsically with depression. But its narrative does come off as a touch preachy and its narrator is not entirely interesting. There’s also the problem of game play. Nihilumbra is a puzzle platformer with few solid puzzles and irritating platforming that consists of predetermined stages of play. These areas shift as you move along instead of the screen following your character. It’s off-putting at first then it becomes truly annoying as you die to enemies situated directly out of your view or you have to take leaps of faith. The game doesn’t advertise itself with the game play though, but ultimately what it does claim to have falls short. There is great potential here, but it falls short. Nihilumbra has a good name, interesting art, and a nice soundtrack… That’s about it really. If you like those things go for it. If not, I can’t recommend it.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
												Nihilumbra is a short, mild puzzle game with above-average storytelling for a platformer. Normal Mode is fun, though not challenging, and there are many worlds, enemies, powers, and ideas to encounter on your journey to escape the nothingness.Void Mode (unlocked after completing the game) is completely unforgiving, which I suppose can still be fun if you like dying instantly after every screen transition.The combination of a mostly dark color scheme with the protagonist's colorful "flower-powers" is a good contrast visually, but it also serves to effectively set the protagonist apart from their origin. They grow in many ways as they travel, or rather, run for their existence.The deep, velvetly voiceover suits the air of the game well, while the music and sound design are light and fitting, but ultimately forgettable.Overall, it's pretty fun, and it's nice to see this kind of existential theme discussed in a type of game that usually doesn't.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												There are a lot of nit picky things that you could say about this game. Like the fact that you can't use your mouse roller to choose diffrent colors so in the middle of trying to stop a red color from killing you, you must go to the corner and click the purple and in trying to do that the red color burns you to death. Then you have to go to the last check point which in most cases is very far away from where you were. What makes that more frustrateing is that the check point that would have saved you was two feet away.       But then there are some really annoying things about it like the fact that if you die and there is a point where the narrator talk he will repeat it and if you die a lot he will repeat it AGAIN AND AGAIN.  Is the narrator suppost to be my conscious? He would always say stuff like "You should feel bad" "You feel guilt" it was kinda like gauntlet where the wizard says PLAYER 2 IS HUNGRY. Except the wizard only said that when it was necessary not every 2 seconds.     It was like the narrator was trying to make me feel bad for this little black thing that had no personality or backstory.And he kept trying to remind you that HEY DONT FORGET TO FEEL AWFUL. Sometimes he would blatenly say something along the lines of you should just kill yourself because you were "ruining" the places you were leaving behind.         The puzzles are not challangeing and the monsters in the game make inovative and new ways to solve them impossible and they are so repetitive that you die 3000 times before you can get to the next checkpoint. Sometimes there is a part of the void that is plastared onto the scenery so it is impossible to try new ways to solve the puzzles. The scenery is bland and the game itself is very repetitive. There is no real story at all to it except to run away from the void. No reason to why I want to do this no reason to why I am in the places I am. It was cute at first but then it just got annoying and was no longer fun to play and had absolutly no replay value. It had a lot of potential and I was really excited to play it but in the end it was not worth the money.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2016
												This is a puzzle game. The controls are sticky and it's hard to choose between the tools quickly, which becomes frusterating immediately. it also feels like your character is slogging through a sea of jello, which is probably intentional, but coupled with the stickyness of the controls and the hurtbox on the character being severely disjointed becomes a source of perpetual annoyance. So the contols are annoying, but that isn't what breaks the game.What really breaks the game is the narration. This voice is never explained and makes no sense in the context. This is on almost every screen and is like a mosquito buzzing in your ear the entire time. You can mute the narration but you can't make the subtitles go away. Not only does this voice basically solve every early puzzle for you it also tries to tell you how to feel in the game. THIS IS BAD CONVEYANCE. If you want me to feel like the game is hopeless, make the game translate that. Don't just shove it down my throat and expect me to think that way.TL;DR: Bad controls, Insanity inducing narration.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
												Nihilumbra is a short, mild puzzle game with above-average storytelling for a platformer. Normal Mode is fun, though not challenging, and there are many worlds, enemies, powers, and ideas to encounter on your journey to escape the nothingness.Void Mode (unlocked after completing the game) is completely unforgiving, which I suppose can still be fun if you like dying instantly after every screen transition.The combination of a mostly dark color scheme with the protagonist's colorful "flower-powers" is a good contrast visually, but it also serves to effectively set the protagonist apart from their origin. They grow in many ways as they travel, or rather, run for their existence.The deep, velvetly voiceover suits the air of the game well, while the music and sound design are light and fitting, but ultimately forgettable.Overall, it's pretty fun, and it's nice to see this kind of existential theme discussed in a type of game that usually doesn't.

content:
Posted: October 1, 2014
												This game is a peculiar thing...first off, it IS a game and it isn't bad, BUT it is a curious mix of genres, some form of art and random stuff. It is neither a platformer nor a puzzle game initially (more on that later).You are a voidling, you escape the void and you're on the run. The void is chasing you with monsters and directly in 1 "boss" level per stage. There are 5 stages in the game, not a whole lot. You can play through the game in about 2-3 hours. It is not difficult. Basically you gain 1 new ability per stage in the form of colours (ice, moss, sand, fire and electricity) with which you have to beat the rather short levels. After you gain fire you can actually kill enemies yourself from time to time. As I said you do neither a lot of platforming nor puzzling. 98% of the stages are self explanatory. Perhaps this is more of a visual and thoughtful journy, as you are accompanied by a narrator, who is almost constantly babbling something I didn't really care anything about, and possibly acts as your inner voice, telling a story about regret, fate etc. blabla. As you are running away from the void it devours the lands you travel, making you directly responsible for the destruction on the earth. Maybe that's the message. After you have beaten the game you unlock "void mode", a kind of alternate hard mode for the game. This is where stuff could get interesting, but I can't force myself to play through it, because here the game really becomes a puzzle platformer and I'm not interested in spending the time for this, but for anyone who is interested in that, you have to endure the normal mode first. Void mode is for you to clean up the void and restore the earth...whatever.For a few bucks this game provides some entertainment in my opinion, but it's in the end just mediocre and a bit strange.By the way, no controller support, which makes sense, because you have to "paint" with your mouse cursor. Would be difficult with a controller.TL;DR: nice game, if somewhat strange concept and annoying moral story. Has additional puzzle hardmode after completion. Pick up for low price.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2015
OverviewOh god, I cannot remember how many times I have forgot how to spell/say the name of this game. Nihilumbra. Nihilumbra is a very original indie platformer that is actually very deep. The narration explains the character, Born, and his thoughts. Of course, assuming that they are a he. It's fairly standard 2D platforming here, except that it introduces the concept of drawing colours across the landscapes. You will use colours to solve the many puzzles in this, admittedly short game's, levels and defeating the many enemies the void throws at you. I won't spoil the lovely narration in the game however, that you can experience for yourself. However, after finishing the main story you unlock void mode. Which is boring as hell. Honestly, the game isn't really suited to dashing about and disposing with various void enemies in different and pretty frustrating ways. I honestly couldn't be bothered with it.Positive+ Great Narrative+ Moving Story+ Fun Platforming+ Colour MechanicsNegative- Void Mode- Short PlaytimeConclusionA very interesting game, with beautiful artwork and a fun colour mechanic but... void mode is just painfully boring. It would have been much better to extend the main story mode of the game. Overall, a great indie title and particularly because it's fairly cheap.

content:
Posted: June 5, 2014
												Nihilumbra does not feel much like a puzzle game. Progression through each level is often done with ease, and as a platformer it also fails to deliver a challenge. Regardless, it's enjoyable. The simple gameplay feels nice, and allows you to appreciate the beautiful visuals and the simple but intriguing narrative. The Void creatures were creatively designed, and encountering each of them was perhaps what I most liked about the game. As a puzzle game it falls short, but it's a really good game anyway.For Linux usersAchievements aren't implemented for 64-bit Linux. If you want to unlock achievements, set Nihilumbra's launch options through Steam to "linux32 %command%" (without quotes) to run the 32-bit version of the game. If you already have a 64-bit save started, I talk a little bit about transferring them here, but be aware that the unlock times for the previously earned achievements will all be set to the time at which you load the save in 32-bit.

Posted: June 25, 2016
												Got this during the summer sale, and gotta say that it really does nto deserve the "very positive" that its overall rating gives it, and especially not worth the 8 bucks. I'll list some pros and cons real quick.Pros: -interesting concept, both in game mechanics and in worldbuildingcons: -scribbly graphics, not interesting to look at (doesn't fit the aesthetics, entity graphics and world graphics incongruent)          -a tendency to fill a level with mostly easy puzzles, then one impossible one out of nowhere (just bad design)          -very uncreative enemy names, designs, etc. (immersion-breaking and incongruent with game's themes)          -a narrator that's both irritating, refuses to stop holding your hand throughout the game, refuses to just shut up and let the player play, badly written monologue, and no one can tell if he's rooting for you, or trying to get you to give up. (just plain inexcusable)          -poorly executed central game mechanic, introducing unintuituve controls (controls intuitive, powers uninteresting)All in all, wonderful concept, poor execution, takes itself too seriously, very low quality. 2/10

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 5, 2016
												This a weird game but it's also kinda interesting.What bugs me about it is the fact that everything is spelled out. The writing is not of a high enough quality to make it literarily valuable. And the level design suffers from the repetitiveness. The narrator talks as if he was the game designer, shoving every meta concept down your throat. And everything is established way too much. I'd appreciate it if it was a little more subtle.Although the art is very elaborate, some objects seem like they were done by a different person. They do not blend together seamlessly. And some of them are not cohesive in the game world. Like the laser turrets and everything mechanical.The gameplay reminds me a little of Trine and Scribblenauts, because you draw into your surroundings while being in a sidescrolling platformer. So it is actually a puzzle game. Coloring the surfaces is a little like the gels in Portal 2. You have one that makes you bounce, one that makes you fast... but there are a couple more. It's acually not bad.There are a few beginner's traps - stuff you can't possibly foresee and walk right into. Also when you enter a new screen it may happen that you get killed instantly. It's good to have a lot of checkpoints, though. But you will hear the same lines of the narrator repeatedly.The experience would be better when the narrator would have talked in a made-up language or if you heard undefined, mysterious soundeffects together with the onscreen text.The controls are fine and so is the music.It feels very indy but also as if they were trying a little too hard to reinforce this notion. It was probably made by someone who is not a game designer first.

number of helpful: 26 of 52 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 17, 2015
												I didn't really enjoy this as much as I thought I would, playing through the main quest. Once you finish it, the game opens up into a 'void' challenge which is significantly harder than the (easy) main storyline. I didn't enjoy it. It's not a 'revisit' or 'redo' of the original story line levels, but it focuses more on killing void creatures in thos enviroments, rather than exploring and puzzles.Main storyline took me 2 hours, and i'm not a big fan of difficult platformers, so I had no interest in what may of been a longer definently more challenging mode. Honestly the controls themselves didn't lend themselves to faster paced more difficult platforming/killing, so even if i was grooving on the idea, i can assure you the controls would of kicked me out just as quickly as the narration.I feel the narrator was relatively unessesary, and many of the lines of dialogue, i really felt were out of place, or didn't mesh well with the story. Honestly, it's game where the narration should really add to it, but more often than not i felt it pulling me out of the game because of lines i didn't expect or just lines that broke the feeling. I normally go into this game expecting a big point, or big plot or big overarching theme 'redemption' 'exploration' 'overcoming of one's greif' 'growing up' honestly, I didn't feel any particular ONE theme from this game... and that saddens me because it could of been as enjoyable to me as Thomas was Alive if it had one thing and explored it well, rather than trying to touch on multiple things at once.Unique mechanics, not particularly engaging though, and marred with questionable narration and thematic choices...Get it really cheap for 2 hours of entertainment, more if you enjoy the more punishing execution style platformers, but be aware the mechanics themselves don't lend themselves well to the platform genres need of smooth, precise gameplay. It's a game that would of benefited more from a longer storyline or a more crisp singular point, than a second challenge mode and shorter story line. The story failed to buy me in, and so I was left, ultimately disappointed.

content:
Posted: July 25, 2016
OverviewYou solve the puzzles, deal with various purple monsters and progress by painting parts of the platform with 5 different colours, each of which has its own property: slide, bounce, sticky, burn and electricity. There are 5 areas in the game, each with its own environment and colour scheme. Within each area you can take your time until the last level which is always a speed run where you are chased by the Void (a purple wave covering the whole screen).The graphics are beautiful and the gameplay itself adds to the beauty as you paint the scenery. The devs are clearly proud of their work, and rightly so, as their gallery of rough sketches and gameplay development is gradually unlocked throughout the game.Steam trading cards and achievements are included and it's cross-platform (I'm a Linux user so that's a big plus for me).No performance issues or glitches at all. Very stable and smooth.Early GameNearly all of the negative reviews of this game show less than 4 hours of gameplay, which means they are only reviewing the Story Mode part of the game, of which there are 41 levels that seem endless. The gameplay at this stage is very easy, I would say the first 70% is child level. The whole time you are subjected to an extremely irritating narrator droning on about hopelessness and death and giving clues to the gameplay, as if it wasn't easy enough already. I was sorely tempted to throw in the towel like so many other reviewers but I wanted to get all the achievements so I carried on. I'm so glad I did!Void ModeAs it turned out, this is a 'game of two halves'. Void Mode is properly challenging, one of the best puzzle platformers I've ever played. I'm talking 50+ attempts at some levels involving timing and accuracy, and that's after you've worked out how to solve it in the first place which isn't easy either. The narrator has disappeared by this point too, replaced by a subtle background tune, just what you need for concentration. Many of the solutions took a lot of brainpower but none were impossible if I thought about it for long enough.AftermathAfter beating Void the 'polyglot language' is unlocked. All the menus etc are slang/internet speak. You can play through Story Mode again and this time there are funny comments from the developer and interesting insights into the game concepts. It's strange because after Void Mode it seems to take no time at all to speed through the entire game (this is the same playthrough that seemed to take forever the first time!) If you reach the 'True End' you will find out what the Void represents.Finally, I cleared up half a dozen of the remaining achievements which, having completed Void, were entertaining but not too difficult (but would have seemed impossible without all my previous experience).In retrospect the Story Mode is nothing more than an extended tutorial. If the developers left Void Mode open from the start instead of forcing you to play through the entire Story Mode to unlock it then players who were getting bored of Story would attempt Void and go scurrying back to Story because they would realise they need the practice and that there is a decent game ahead. I'm sure doing this simple thing would prevent most of the negative reviews.Minor ConsFullscreen only, no windowed mode.No controller support, although this may have been left out deliberately. It would be better for moving around but the painting side of it just wouldn't be feasible with a controller, it needs a mouse.64-bit Linux doesn't upload achievements to your profile but there's a workaround - it's Linux, of course there is :)ConclusionThis is excellent value considering the low price vs amount of gameplay. Apart from the initial Story Mode section (which I now understand was a necessary evil), the vast majority of the 32 hours I've spent playing this game have been fun and rewarding. I highly recommend it as long as you have the patience to work through the 2-4 hours at the beginning before you get to the meaty part of the game.Hot tip: use right-click to quickly erase - it's much easier than selecting it and you will need to know this for some of the quick-fire later levels.I bought this game myself but have dedicated the review to the fabulous and generous people at Steamified.This review is part of the Steamified Community Review program. For similar reviews and fantastic giveaways please visit http://www.steamified.com/.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 3
												This follows a long line of puzzle platformers and it really hits the spot. The history of puzzle platformers is a long one and very much is a genre I've always loved. Way back in the 90s there were many. Usually cartoony in form and had stories and plots. Original Prince of PErsia fits this bill but with the Playstation came 3D and very cartoony characters like Crash Bandicoot and Spyro and such. Also in the past shooting has been part of the mix. But the indie wave since about 2010 had taken things back to its 2D sidescrolling roots and added an art to it that was so new and appealingly fresh. The biggest addition to this line was Limbo. A totally beautiful game. A game that was totally the opposite of lots of platform sidescroller shooters from before as it not only featured a helpless protagonist that was relentlessly tortured throughout the game but had an artistic style and statement that just was pure beauty. So goes Nihilumbra. Yes Nihilism. It's not just for Lebowski fans anymore. This is another success in this genre and it really taps into the most fun bits of Portal 2. Remember the goo levels? This game features a lot of things like that. YOu have this character, this blob...this "nothing". That escapes "the void". And he mimics the form of a scarecrow. I LOVE this choice. Your ragdoll man floats and blows along. He doesn't walk. He kind of floats. And his "clothes" are always flopping in the breeze and especially when he lands from jumps. It's so appealing of a character. LIke the best of disney sidekicks. And then you have gruesome bizarre monsters. Think of all the craziest scariest designs from Dr Seuss or Tex Avery. Stuff of nightmares in shape and form because all these things are alive. And there are different ways to avoid and outsmart these creatures. And traverse this world. Okay now....the guy. There is a narrator that comes across like one of those positive self help cassettes. Always telling you your place in this world. Telling you what a failure you are. Telling you how waful your life has been. Telling you you will never win. And then reinvigorating you with his soothing tones what a success you will be, are being, will continue to be. You are special and goshdarnit people like you, Stewart Smalley. I still don't know what to make of this really. The narrator gives you all the instruction for the game. And then visual aids appear in a lot of places to tell you EXACTLY how to solve a puzzle. In fact they don't wait for more than about 2 failures before the game actually tells you how to solve a puzzle. I am not sure if it does that all the time. Maybe just when you are learning a new move? But I see it often. I've conquered the first two worlds thus far. I guess that means levels. And each world seems to offer new types of gameplay and monsters and moves. Very much like Portal 2 did. More moves and thus more puzzles you solve for those moves then puzzles combining those moves and monsters with previous ones to remind you. It does do a bunch of handholding for sure. But I do feel satisfied playing it. It's like relaxing in a hot tub. And when the swirly purple void emcompasses me...and the whole screen. I don't mind. It's beautiful. Well....unless of course well yes I do mind when it is chasing me and I'm trying to plan for moves that haven't come on the screen yet because...the ....screen....is....scrolling....by....so........S....L...O...W...L...Y.... However any frustrating bits so far have been solved with a few tries, trial and error and whatnot. Seeing how you die and then remembering and preparing for that offscreen jump. And it is satisfying changing the ground to grassy bouncy, maybe just a LITTLE less satisfying to shooting goop everywhere with a goopgun. I'm liking it. It's a satisfying PP...and a satisfying experience. I'll let the narrator lull me with his dulcet tones and float away in my scarecrow body. I really love the animation of the characters by the way. And the scenery and weather are just gorgeous. This is also one that goes on sale a lot from it's list price of just 8 dollars so it's a steal when it does. Get it.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 16, 2016
												I've got mixed feelings on this game. Overall it was a good experience and a relaxing platformer/puzzler to play over an evening. The puzzles were ridiculously easy (except for a handful that were mainly dependent on perfect timing) for any adult, which normally I'm fine with so long as the story is interesting; however, the story was really nothing interesting at all with awful narration that was horribly redundant and rarely revealed anything interesting. The game mechanics for the puzzles were fun - but they clashed with the way side-scrolling was implemented by sliding in/out each background/scene instead of a single continuous level. Most of the trouble I had with puzzles was due to the mechanics clashing with side-scrolling, but not in a fun way that seemed intended at all. Toward the end I started wanting to just finish the game already, and found myself enjoying it less and less.Pros - Nice artwork, and sound was decent- Fun game mechanics (painting colors on surfaces)- Relaxing platformer/puzzler gameplay that never left me frustratedCons- Short (I like short games now and then, but I know it will irk others)- Way too easy (Solutions were always always obvious at first glance without any thought)- Story was bland and repetitive, if you can even call it a story - Narrator was getting annoying- Only challenges were unintended annoyances due to side-scrolling implementation- Lots of glitches with getting stuck on certain surfaces (causing character stuttering and sound repeating)

content:
Posted: July 31, 2015
												I did finish the game. Some of it was very fun. I love to figure out puzzles. But once into the Void levels, it became so frustrating that I considered abandoning the game. Instead I referred to a walkthrough to help out. It was never that the puzzles were hard to figure out. It was the timing that was so critical in some cases. A second or less could make the difference in not getting through an obstacle.There were times you needed to bounce so high that the figure you were controlling would go off the top of the screen. This made it very tough to "stick" a landing or bounce just right. There was no way to avoid death repeatedly because you could not see the next screen of obstacles/enemies until you were in the line of fire or off the edge of a cliff.  I could not find any way to change the key mappings/bindings. So, I was stuck using WASD. That means my fingers were in the wrong position to quickly tap on numbers to change colors, I had to rely on the mouse wheel which means cycling through colors which takes more time than desired.  There were times I just left the game up in paused mode because I did not want to replay a prior part of a level (no save nearby). So the number of hours it took me to play is highly inflated with 8 hours while I slept or worked.For me, these frustration points were just too many. Yet, as always, I feel good having completed the game. I even played all of the extra levels that get unlocked once the void levels are completed. I actually enjoyed those extra levels and their pithy monologues more than the void levels. Those were hilarious and informative about the game's development.However, I can not see any replay value. So if you choose to play the game, consider waiting for a sale.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
												Honestly, I expected much less from this game than I actually got. Till now, I didn't know a really good game from Spain, but this really changed my mind. The story is not that impressive, it's just a guy telling you something about life and comments the 'colors' you found, so that's not really a game to shed tears. On the other hand, the game requires you to use common sense, which means you only have to have a piece of brain to be able to pass through the whole game, the skill is not that required, it's more about repeating till you get it. The story line is more for people who want to get into calm mood, but reversed, void mode is for those, who really want to enjoy it and they do not mind repeating one part of game thousand times.Pros:Nice interface, the game is about void and the UI really looks like that.Usage of common senseThe enviroment changes progressively, you do not insensibly pass through random maps.Void difficulty is extremely funnyPlatformer with unique mechanicsCons:It is way too short - I would like to play, but repeating maps is not that fun. If it had some kind of multiplayer, it would be great. Like you would have a chance to make your map, people would play it and that would be ranked by time, or you could be able to make a whole mod or something, but currently, it was pretty short.Difficulty gap - The first difficulty was totally easy, but when I came to void difficulty, but I raged more than when I played Dark Souls, but as I stated above, you can pass through the game with zero skill, it is just repeating and common sense, but if there was some middle difficulty, it would at least make a game longer and people who are not that patient would at least be able to pass it.8/10

												I think the concept here is decent, but... they really don't know what to do with it. The main game is too easy and basically feels like an extended tutorial. 												This game.. ohh Boy this game just bleeds personality, and yet your "character" technically isint even alive, you have escaped the never ending maw of the Void, the Entropy of the Universe manifested in physical form, Why do you exist? should you Exist? are the questions you ask yourself as you venture through this game.Gameplay wise its fun, you obtain colour powers that allow you "paint" the world, to aid in light platforming/puzzle solving, and to avoid the creepy dark creatures the Void has created to stop you from fleeing it, it has a nice feel using your mouse pointer to paint the ground with ice to slide, or use Electric currents to power circuit boxes.To top that off there is a wonderfully almost sinister Narrator guideing you through the game, He questions your existance, even telling you your not strong enough to move forward.. yet you do cause you are a new being in a mysterious world, but no this.The Void is Eternal.. The Void cannot be stopped.. it will chase you to the ends of the Earth.. The Void must be made Whole again....Note that 4 hours was the length to for me to complete the first "part" of the game, a much Harder Second part is unlocked when you complete part 1.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2014
												I'll be honest: after finishing Nihilumbra, I quite disliked it.  It tries to establish a mood with a constant narration, in the style of Bastion.  But the writing is mediocre and the voice acting is boring, so the entire thing comes off as trite and cliche.  I was just about to uninstall the game and never think about it again, when I decided on a whim to quickly try out 'Void Mode'.  Void Mode, unlocked once you complete the main game, is a new game + of sorts.  You start over with all powers unlocked, and are tasked with going through the game again.  However, things are much harder.  There are entirely new setpieces, enemies, and mechanics that really force you to think about things.  All voice acting and story elements are removed.  Void Mode is when the game really comes into itself as a puzzle platformer, and I found completing it genuinely satisfying and enjoyable.  I'm recommending the game for Void Mode alone.  If you're looking for a good puzzle platformer, rush through the main game and enjoy Void Mode.  If you're looking for a story-driven experience, I suggest you give this one a miss.

Posted: December 30, 2013
												Nihilumbra is a fun little indie that has a good bit of platforming and can be related to  super meat boy in some small aspects.It can give you a few good hours of fun, and if you are looking at this because of the community choice sale going on as I type this, it is a good idea to buy it for only $2.99. Some people seem to dislike the placement of the autosave locations, but there is a reason you can't save wherever. Most platformers don't do it that way for a reason. The narrator adds a little bit of fun to it, and the puzzles progressively get harder and entertaining. If you are very good at platformers, I can recommend this. If you are meh at platformers, I can STILL recommend this as it is very simple to learn and it teaches you perfectly.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2014
												Should probably caution on the fact that:1) the game is very short (I beat it in 2 hours, this is without the challenge modes though).2) the game is very easy (minus the challenge modes).Now with those out of the way, let me say that Nihilumbra could be a hidden gem. It's just as good as some of the other indie greats like FEZ, Braid, or even Super Meat Boy (except, again, this game is way easier than those). The game makes use an intresting macanic where you paint surfaces with different colors that all have different effects - somewhat reminds me of Portal. If you want a game with logic puzzle like Portal (minus the humor though because this game gets somewhat depressing) and are okay with a short length like Portal then this game is for you. Although I say the game is easy, the Challenge mode after beating the game really is hard, but I still feel like the game is only giving me the difficultys of "Press A to win" Easy, and "Start the game to die" Hard.

content:
Posted: March 27
												I like puzzles but I don't really like the type of game that makes you die 50 times trying to figure out what to do.  That's what kind of game this is, at least once you get into void mode.   You begin the game in story mode which takes about 2.5 hours and is pretty dull.  Basically a tutorial on the different types of abilities you can use.   You are never really challenged in story mode and then the difficulty immediately goes up to ridiculous in void mode.   It's frustrating because you have to paint the walls with the various colors and every time you get killed you have to repaint everything until you get it perfect.  This kind of game has to balance the frustration with the fun and it does not do it well.

												This is seriously creepy. No, not this game. But the fact that Beautifun snuck into my house with some kind of brain scanner and, after completely profiling the entirity of my memories and thoughts, decided to make a game specifically for me. Ok, maybe I am being a bit narcissistic and it wasn't made specifcally for me, but I feel like it was because I loved every moment (and every pixel of every moment) of it.Everything from the beautiful aesthetic (including the enemies) to the wonderous narrative, to the challenging, yet managable platforming. Though solving puzzles with the colors (metaphor through mechanics) is the best part. Honestly I couldn't even imagine a game of this scope being any more enjoyable to me than this. While you might not enjoy it quite as much as I did you will certainly like it a lot if you like 2d puzzle/platformer games.

number of helpful: 8 of 19 people (42%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 10, 2014
												I usually try to recommend stuff overall, but when there are so many better platformers (both old and newer ones) which are somehow getting less attention than this "barely average" game, I can't, and won't be recommending this.Controls are good, mechanics are good and stable, visuals are kind of OK, soundtracks are not too bad, and that's literally all the positive (If you consider "kind of OK" and "not too bad" as positive.) aspects of the game. On the other hand, there are like a dozen negative (and I mean, NEGATIVE) aspects. Puzzles and application of mechanics are just dreadful, boring, and repetitive. It feels like mechanics are there, not because they'll be the foundation of the game, but because they'll efficiently waste your time with silly tutorial-like levels (Whole game consists of them, not just the 'mechanic introduction' parts.). Camera is a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ I won't even try to describe it. Story is non-existent. Narrator is a disaster, it's the exact opposite of the narration at 'Thomas was Alone', where narration completes the advancement of story, while simultaneously making you wonder he'll say next. Instead, you'll just curse at that damn nonsensical boring text-reading voice each and every second (It won't even be catching up with your progress speed.), while playing a more boring game (If you still may play this game despite this review, do youself a favor, and mute the narrator right away. Don't even try getting into game for the first time, thinking like "How bad could it be?", just, don't..). Also, name of the game is Nihilumbra, but both in terms of concept and story, it has nothing to do with Nihilism whatsoever. Creators must've thought like "Void = Nothing = Nihilism", or something shalow like that, just to seem cool. By the way, 'Void' is a purple wave which absorbs everything, more like a blackhole. Last but not least, typography in this game is a ♥♥♥♥ING TORTURE. Trust me, as a graphic designer, I've endured many bad typographies throughout my life, but this game has by far the WORST typography I've ever seen in any digital content. My eyes bleed several times, that huge serif typeface haunted me in my nightmares.And as a result, I consider Nihilumbra as an incredibly awful waste of a potentially above-average concept.If you finished literally all the great platformers out there, like Limbo, Braid, Teslagrad, Thomas was Alone, FEZ, The Swapper, The Cave, Trine, Mark of the Ninja, and you are still searching for a platformer, it may barely be OK to buy Nihilumbra on a -%80 sale..

number of helpful: 4 of 11 people (36%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												You are a (not) evil blob thing born of the void, and decide (I think) you want to live and blossom into a healthy, young and bright upstanding adult.StoryI'll be frank, the story is really bare bones and overly convoluted and just outright idiotic in it's narrative.  You'll be hearing some guy almost talk to himself and keep switching his opinions of what YOU should be feeling about the situation instead of coming to that conclusion yourself and is incredibly contradictory about 90% of the situation.  He also loves stating the obvious, assuming you have the intelligence of single celled organisms.GraphicsProbably the only decent aspect of the game.  The sprites have a decent amount of variation, but the environments and overall aesthetic feels like some old mobile phone game to be perfectly honest.  As there's only 4 zones (5 if you include the unlockable Void zone) the variation in art and enemy type is extremely limited.GameplaySo as you progress, you'll acquire different colors which adds a few abilities to your arsenal (such as blue being the "ice" color, increasing speed and having enemies slip over themselves).  Unfortunately the puzzles themselves are either extremely straight forward, requiring little to no thinking, or so stupidly broken that you end up dying due to bad enemy placement and level design before figuring out how to avoid the scenerio (and even then it still is a bit RNG if you end up falling on an enemy off screen).  Even the narrator will neglect to tell you of a new enemy until AFTER straight up dying to it, and then restate the obvious of what you figured out after passing it, like the game assumed you somehow cheated to get past or something.  Supposedly after beating the storyline, you unlock Void Mode which is supposedly harder, but after getting a taste of the base game's puzzle and level design I can tell you with 100% certainty you will just end up dying 50 times before memorizing a pattern and avoiding it.  That isn't skill or a measure of difficulty folks.ControlsThe controls are honestly either okay or genuinely confusing.  You can use WASD or the arrow keys to move while your mouse is your paint brush of sorts, which seems logical.  Even using the scroll button to cycle through your colors seems okay.  Then you want to get to your color remover, and for whatever reason the game won't let you scroll to it, you need to click the icon on the top right bit of your screen which whips out a large tree branch with all the colors on it, then click the one you want.  Why they only did it for that is beyond me.  Also there is no controller support.SoundThe music is actually pretty good, IF I COULD HEAR IT OVER THIS IDIOT NARRATOR.  Sure I could turn the voice volume down to 0, but I shouldn't have to do that over something that is supposed to be relatively important since every once in a blue moon he will give out a helpful tip.  So I'm stuck with him and his irritating self patronizing voice.Final VerdictHow did this get so many positive reviews?  Seriously?  If this game was 3.99 or something I could maybe justify it as an experience, but I got this baby on sale for 1.99 and actually canceled my refund ticket solely because of the fact that I needed to write a review of reason and maybe spare someone from paying the full price, or even buying this at all.  This is a decent phone app game, nothing more (and with no more then 3-4 hours total playtime WITH Voidmode unlocked it is not worth the mileage either).

content:
Posted: June 17, 2014
												Nihilumbra has you control a being who is questioning it's existence, in a sprawling, puzzle-filled world. Unfortunately, I could not connect with this game.The game has merits: the puzzles all work, there's no bugs (at least none that I encountered) and everything works as it should. The puzzles aren't challenging, but they are what they are, a little lite puzzle adventure. Now, on to the reasons I wouldn't recommend the game. I could not get over the narrator. I'm sorry, maybe it was just me, but it bothered me so much. The line delivery wasn't great and the tone and tambre of the voice seemed purely to rely on being deep and kind-of sounding like a movie-trailer guy to bring any depth to the words spoken. For me, it really irked me. Then, the story. I didn't like it. It was confusing, a little pretencious, and a little forced. The game felt as though the creator had came up with the idea for the puzzles and bent a story around it to package it. Maybe you'll enjoy it, have a look over the trailer and see what you think, but for me, I sadly did not.Nilesy

												There are two games in here. One of them is a fairly easy and short puzzle game, with some tacky/artsy story. The second is punishing platformer, sometimes with time pressure, combined with what might otherwise be a reasonable/interesting puzzle game. The "sweet spot" for difficulty lies in the exlcuded middle of these two games. I should probably give the second more of a chance, but honestly, I can't care enough to load this back up. Oh, and you can't play the second until you've unlocked it, by beating the first (~2 hours).

number of helpful: 3 of 9 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 14, 2015
This is a review as someone who is slower than others.Nihilumbra was a..odd game for me, Think as if you went to a fine diner, The people who work there are nice, The place is neat and tidy with a touch of low priced food, The same low priced food that looks wonderful but ends with a rather sour taste.Story: Not quite a masterpiece but far from being a best seller.The story is you are born as a piece of void who escapes the emptiness of it all, You move from place to place picking up new colors and learning more about the world around you, Sadly you do not have much time to learn about these places as the void not only sends monsters to destory you but also comes after you itself. In your luck, A voice assists you on the way, Telling you of the void and it's creatures. Who this voice is exactly, We never know, It can't be a voice in our head because our character does not know these things until the voice tells so. Graphics: Fits for it's lore and stays in a nice place.I'm not much as a graphics freak so most of the time it doesn't matter, But the graphics are quite nice since they are hand drawn. Since this was a mobile port moved to PC, I feel they did a good job. One thing I do love is how much detail is given to your character. When you push a item, Your "feet" will actually push against the ground to push said object, Pay attention to your character, You might see something new.Puzzles: Oh wow Look at all the pretty colors..Ack, Most likely the worst part of the game. As someone who's thinking is not quite fast as others, This game can be very unfair as fast reflexes and thinking is needed. Most of the puzzles are very bland and easy to figure out, Some did take many tries for me, But I feel that was more on my part. The color mechanic could have been used much better but the depth of the puzzle do not drop far from the flower. Most of them are pushing boxes to leave on a button or getting past an enemy, Which would have been fine if they had a bit more variety would have made it where it wasn't so tedious.Music: Wait? You can only unlock old timey mode AFTER you beat the game?The music fits the game very well, but since I was raging more over the puzzles, It was too hard to pay attention. Old timey mode sounds great but I really wish you could have had it for the whole game because I actually ended up prefering it.Final feelings: I wish I could play void mode.I wish there was a "maybe" on recommending games because I feel right in the middle about this game.Not sure if I would come back and play it due to the sometimes downright ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t puzzles, But I do feel the game holds a good spot on my top 50 favorite games, It's empty yes but it's good while it lasts but the end just left such a bitter taste in my mouth that I really can't say I would recommend this game, I mean it's a good indie piece, And the translation wasn't broken up or off-putting but, The puzzles are the core of this game and if the core is bitter, You might not want to take another bite.Rating: 5/10 I'm happy that I got it free but make sure to catch it during a sale.
