content:
Posted: December 2, 2014
												Summary: A good looking side-scrolling platform puzzler which offers little challenge and presents its story in a very overbearing fashion. Severe pacing problems left me bored and unwilling to complete it. First impression: I won’t say review, because I will not be finishing the game. I made it to the third area (Ash desert) and it still feels like I’m in the tutorial. The game holds your hand despite not offering anything resembling a challenge. I assume that it becomes more interesting later in the game when you have more abilities that can interact. Moreover, I do not question the benefits of letting the player get used to the basics first and gradually increase the difficulty, but why let the game go on so long before doing so? While many games are able to present interesting challenges with a single mechanic, this one had not presented anything interesting even by my third ability.  The game looks good and the narrator is competent. Unfortunately the narration, which otherwise would be the game’s strong point, feels like it is trying to force me to feel something rather than letting me feel it. Rather than explaining what Born is feeling or thinking, it is saying that I am Born and “You are sad, you feel guilty, you will not escape.” In contrast to, for example, Thomas Was Alone, I felt completely disconnected to the story. The combination of severe pacing problems and an overbearing narration makes me not recommend Nihilumbra. Sure, it is a cheap game and it looks good, but it is also boring.

												This is nothing really redeeming about this game.The game play is mediocre but is sadly the best part of the game. You get 5 colors that change the environment but you rarely need to use more then 1 at a time. And there is nothing about the colors really inventive, it is just there.The graphics are just lazy. The main character has some nice animations, but everything else is just the bare minimum to get the point across. The all scary void is just a flat image that lights certain parts in a sequence, reminding me of a Christmas tree.The voice actor is bad. Just reminds me of free flash game voice actors. He also reads the wrong word in the game ending making the sentence make no sense. To make that mistake worse, the intend sentence is written on the background, just so you know he screwed up.The worst part of the game is the script. It is really bad. It is like the some accidentally grabbed the first draft instead of the final one and no one noticed. And these are all thoughts I had while playing the game, but I decide to finish to see if it would redeem itself. The ending was the worst part of it.Final verdict: Do not play it even if they are giving it away for free.

content:
Posted: April 30, 2015
												I really wanted to recommend this game; it has so much going for it, but in the end, I was just angry at it.It's absolutely beautiful. It's almost worth buying just for that. The story is fun, the mechanics are great and very novel. During the first part when you're collecting the colors (game mechanics), the game is super fun, even though it's kinda easy. However, in "Void mode," (which is the real game, honestly), the puzzles are just stupidly hard. And I don't mean they're difficult to figure out (that's the fun part of any puzzle game, right?). What I mean is once you do figure out what to do (and that part is challenging and fun because they don't let you take the obvious route), it's almost impossible to time correctly. The game stops being about figuring out puzzles and starts being about minuscule timing tasks, i.e., try to make an enemy chase you off a ledge and have it step on a button while you rush through the opened area. I'm sorry Nihilumbra. I wanted to like you so much more than I did.tl;dr: Beautiful, fun story, stupidly hard timing/jumping tasks.

content:
Posted: January 27, 2014
												Simply put, I really did not like this game. Many of my complaints are mirrored by other reviewers. The narrator's voice is not very well acted, very repetitious, very trite, and just...constant. He shows up with zingers about finding your heart, how anger is dangerous, how it's important to feel sadness, and at times I found myself blinking in disbelief that the lines made it through to the final draft. The gameplay is mediocre. It isn't outright bad, but it's just not very fun. You spend most of your time trying out different powers, which will give you the ability to: slide yourself and objects over ground, toast things (including you if you're not careful) with raging fires, make the ground 'bouncy' so everything springs off of it, create electricity to turn on circuits (and thus make puzzles 'run' their active elements), and a few others I'm probably forgetting. That's the thing - the abilities are really just forgettable. Platforming staples like 'bouncy bouncy' need a little twist to make them interesting. Otherwise you are just back to Mario and spring-boards again. Personally, I found the story tedious and unoriginal. You play as a sliver of the void, inexplicably cast onto the earth, and running from the 'void' - an understandably featureless foe who chases you across the map on occasion, and summons minions to try and slay you in a few different ways. The rule in this game is Insta-Death, which would be fun and exciting if the monsters were not so often acting in entirely novel ways, reacting unpredictably to tiny mistakes on your behalf (e.g. missing a small spot on the floor with the 'paint-on' effects), or just being RIGHT THERE as you enter a new frame. They also tend to have (IMO) awkward hit-boxes, such that you think you are okay springing over them, only to mysteriously die when you get too close.I finished the main game in a little over two hours. It's a decently priced game, and I don't have much to complain about here. There is a 'void' mode unlocked after beating the main game, but I found the game suddenly veered from stupidly easy, to stupidly hard when I reached this mode - I never found the game reached that 'sweet spot' for me, between the two poles. I found myself, ridiculously, stuck on the very first 'room' of Void mode, perfectly able to solve the 'puzzle' (jumping over a charging enemy by building a little altitude), and occasionally succeeding (only to die on the next room) but almost entirely unable to execute it. Trading Cards are a nice perk, and I sold them for an effective $1 reduction in price.Achievements are what you would expect. About half are for clearing levels and winning the game, or objectives you can't avoid completing. The other are fairly obscure, and I believe there is a handful of hidden ones. Nothing too staggering here, but par for the course.Overall, I disliked this game, and would probably rate it something like 4/10. It wasn't pull-out-your-hair bad, but on reflection, I think it was not worth the money. A couple hours wasted, no harm done, but nothing I can give a 'thumb up' to with a good conscience.

The narration itself is of poor quality, and the message itself is delivered to you in the form of preaching as opposed to letting the story tell itself. People have drawn comparisons to Limbo on this one, but they're not even remotely the same level, and I hate Limbo as is.

number of helpful: 3 of 10 people (30%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
												This game was just... uninteresting. The first few levels were pretty fun, getting used to the whole painting mechanic, but once I played with it for a while it got really boring. I tried hard to like this game, but the more I played, the more I didn't even want to finish it. The story is cliche to say the least, and the narration absolutely ruined it (yes, I know you can turn it off, and I did). Instead of giving you bits and pieces for you to interpret, it shoves it down your throat. In fact, this game barely even has a story. It's kind of like they wanted to make a platformer that incorporated the whole painting technique and THEN they just kind of came up with some boring storyline just so you would feel like you had a reason to run through these levels.The platforming is mediocre to say the least. The screen transitions in this game will absolutely mess you up. In a game where you need to know exactly what is around the corner to prevent your death, you don't get any warnings at all. Most of my deaths in this game were not due to the puzzles being challenging, but due to me not being able to see what I was walking into. You'll just be walking along, get to the end of the screen, the screen will transition and all of a sudden HOLY MOTHER OF GOD AN ENEM- dead.I also found that sometimes I would breeze past a puzzle using a certain method, but if I tried to do that exact same thing in another spot, it wouldn't work. Like the one part where you needed to sneak past one of those flower monsters using the brown colour. Okay, worked fine. Then on the next level I try it again but NO, it didn't work, I had to use green to jump over it or something. I can't really remember, oh well.When it comes to aesthetics the game is.. alright. There are some really nice looking parts in the game but I found that a lot of the background and level design just looked very dull. I think there was only one point in the game where I was walking through the forest across the fallen tree near the waterfalls that I actually said "Wow, this is nice looking and unique and my eyes like it!" other than that the environments were forgettable. The gameplay gets VERY repetitive. You find a flower. You get a new colour that has a different power. You learn how to use the power. You go through the level using the power in very self-explanitory ways. Run from the void. Repeat. The game really just tells you what to do half of the time, the other half is you sitting there saying "what the hell, this should clearly work but it doesn't for some unknown reason".Overall I think I got about 2 hours out of this game, and I was definitely taking my time. I thought maybe I was missing something the whole time, but it was really just that shallow. I'll admit I haven't tried this void mode things yet, but I doubt I will since the main story bored me so much. This game is not worth $10. I repeat, DO NOT WASTE $10 ON THIS. If you're even thinking about buying it, look for a half off coupon or something. Oh jeeze, the more I type about this the more and more I come to dislike it.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2015
												A cheap indie platformer with a bit of story to hold it together.The main gimmick is that you gain access to elements that you can place on the the ground/walls to alter it their properties. E.G. brown makes them sticky, ground bouncy, stuff like that. It's a decent enough concept but the mouse control of it never felt right to me, it's a bit sloppy, as opposed to precise.The puzzles in story mode are deadly easy, so it seems that this mode is more about the plot than anything else. You're a creature from "The Void", basically a hellish nothingness, who escapes and discovers the wonders of the living world while your home realm follows you, putting obstacles in your way and fighting to pull you back. The plot is just meh to me. I don't really go for abstract philosophy, and the narrator is deadpan and annoying. At a couple hours, with too-easy puzzles, story mode felt like a waste of time. Finishing it opens the Void Mode, which ramps up the puzzle difficulty from 2/10 to 12. I didn't enjoy the bit of that that I played either, so overall I'm not happy with this game in any way.

content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
												The game consists of 5 stages that take about 15-20 minutes each to complete. So you'll probably finish the game in about 2 hours or less. In each stage you get a new color that you click and drag across the ground to make it slippery, bouncy, sticky, burn things, or connect electricity. Honestly I was expecting the game to have controller support with such basic controls. It has none; keyboard only.The narration is alright. The gameplay is honestly very boring throughout the first two levels. I was about to give up on the game; I felt no reason to continue playing. I wasn't having fun and it was boring. After forcing myself to keep going it got a little more interesting in the 3rd-5th levels. Overall a fairly average and short game. The file size is fairly big, about 2.3 gb. I usually expect small 2d games like this to be around 500 MB or less. It doesn't really seem to have any replayability and I have no desire to play it again so I just uninstalled it after I beat it. I got it in a humble bundle for $1 with two other games. I've seen it on sale for $1 by itself before too; so pick it up while it's cheap if you want to. I wouldn't recommend it to anyone I know unless they really wanted it or got it very cheap.

content:
Posted: January 12, 2014
												Discover the beautiful world of Nihilumbra and join Born on his adventure to find himself whilst trying to escape from his inevitable curse. Born was created from the absolute nothingness: The Void. But somehow he separates himself from the black emptiness and appears in the world. This is where his long odyssey begins, in which he will learn how to use the colors around him to gain powerful abilities and transform the world. However, his experiences come at a high price. The Void must be one. It seeks to reclaim him and will never stop chasing him, destroying everything in its path along the way. To survive, Born will have to condemn the earth he walks to its inevitable obliteration by The Void... Advise: Nihilumbra has been designed in a way that everyone can enjoy its story, even without previous experience with puzzle games. However, players seeking for a challenge will find it on the second half of the game: the Void Mode.

number of helpful: 4 of 15 people (27%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 16, 2014
												It looked interesting, but I was somewhat disappointed.Art is ok, not exactly fantastic but fitting enough, I've seen far worse. There were some alright relaxing music tunes.Level design didn't feel too great, not impressive or challenging (in story mode; you unlock another mode when finishing the game where you progress through whole new levels and which I played shortly; that mode is apparently harder, but I had no motivation to try that too much). Logic lacks a bit too. Why would you be in a forest and find mechanical devices to block or help you on your way? I didn't remember any explanation for that. I guess gameplay-wise there could have been ways for the developers to make things work the same just with different, more logical and ambiance-fitting objects.There is a constant neutral narration throughout the levels. The voice quickly became tedious to listen to, and I soon didn't care about what he was telling as it felt pretentious and repetitive. The game dearly tries to make you feel like you were on a meaningful journey of life and death, but it didn't strike me. There are some lines so dripping with a tryhard-meaningfulness that I couldn't resist to roll my eyes a bit. Or maybe I'm just hardboiled? I don't know.Regarding the gameplay: You find flowers resembling colors. These colors give you certain powers to draw on surfaces. One color makes you move faster when walking the ground it's on, another makes you (or enemies slower), another makes you jump higher and so on. It's moderately interesting, but not fleshed out too much in the story mode, which is why someone has to get through that first to see the other, already-mentioned second mode in which he can use all these colors to a bigger extend. I didn't exactly like the progression of the game: There are clear lines between the levels and settings. I think it was first an icy area, then a moderate forest, a hot desert, after that some volcano area and one more special place. In each you find one flower/color. I prefer a less narrowly drawn progression in games, as this is a very "classic" or predictable/"boring" scheme (pick your side) to make someone advance through.

Posted: May 25, 2014
												For the most part, I would say it deserves the 75 from Metacritic:  Gameplay is simple at first but comes up with interesting puzzles, the narrator and narration are overwrought, and everything is generally quite nice to look at, especially some of the monsters.  But after you beat the game, there is a challenge mode that is EXTREMELY difficult.  It even has an achievement called "Hard Mode is Hard." for when you die 5 times in Hard mode.  I got that achievement within 10 minutes of starting the hard mode.  I rarely died in the normal game.Now, this will give you one of two reactions:  "Ugh, who has time for this?" and "Aww man, I'm gonna be the best Nihilumbra player ever!!"The 2 factors I would recommend you consider are:  Do you like dark-coloured existentialist narrative wanderings?  And does that Hard Mode entice you?

Posted: January 4, 2014
												I can honesly say, that this is one of the most interesting indie games that I have played!~ The story line is very interactive, as it is you feel for Born, it also has some very fun puzzles for you to do with the various colors that you recieve while advancing in the story. Posted: January 5, 2014
												The game is a platformer with some clever mechanics, divided into two modes. The initial story mode is effectively an extended tutorial with little actual challenge. New mechanics are introduced very slowly, while the plot presented at this point is about what you'd expect from a casual indie game; very forgettable and completely predictable. The atmosphere is pretty nice though, and the voice is pleasant to listen to.Once you finish the story you get access to the extended challenge mode; think Super Meat Boy dark world. The mechanics are much the same, but the game tries to add extra challenge by presenting a lot more complex scenarios. Unfortunately for the most part these extended challenges end up being nothing more than timing puzzles or trial and error memorization of where the enemies spawn.Get this full price if you really like precise timing puzzles. Wait for a sale if you like platformers and artsy games. Skip it if you're looking for deep or thought evoking challenges.

Posted: February 5, 2014
												You enter the world, not knowing who you are, not knowing what to do, chased by "The Void". So what do you do? You run! After each death, it becomes a little easier as you realise what not to do - the game won't always tell you. The game has a relaxed and philosophical feel to it, but there's always a sense of urgency as The Void never sleeps.The soundtrack adds nicely to the mood and it's worth the $4 on Bandcamp.

Posted: April 25, 2014
												Nihilumbra has great art, a soothing soundtrack, wonderfully original puzzle mechanics, and a story that you want to see through to the end.  The different abilities are given to you gradually and appropriately ramp up the complexity of the puzzles at a good pace.  The game is split between two parts: The first time through and all of the the levels re-done as a bonus hard mode (called void mode) once you complete the game.  The first time through the puzzles aren't all that challenging but serve as warm up as you get used to all of the different puzzle mechanics.  The puzzles are never boring, but walk a fine line between being solvable fairly quickly but also satisfying to do so.  After you get to the end, the void mode opens up and really makes you think and be on your toes.  The puzzles are never frustrating but can be quite challenging.  The story is written such that the void mode makes sense narratively and motivates you to want to finish it to get the 2nd (final) ending.  The void mode levels aren't narrated as the main playthrough is which is a bummer, but just a minor complaint.  Very much worth the complete playthrough!

Posted: February 25, 2014
												Nihilumbra started off as an iPhone game that I loved and enjoyed for its story telling. It is like a metroidvania puzzle game that is linear. There are no branching paths like a true metroidvania but story is of more importance than gameplay. That being said the gameplay is well crafted and all the puzzles are solvable with minimal intrusion, this is not like early point and click adventure game puzzles but more of an actio-adventure sort in 2D. The Steam version has an added art gallery and full voice over. THe voice over is nice but is not needed, though having played both versions it was a nice addition, but I still think the voice over work is more like a director's commentary and shouldn't be heard the first time around. It is one of my favorite indie games to come out in the past year or so.So yes, buy this game for the experience. It's better than Limbo, and about as good (if easier) than Braid.

Posted: January 1, 2014
												Nihilumbra, by Beautifun Games, is one of those games; when stumbled upon and given time, you really get to see all the heart it holds, and the care it had been given. When you are introduced to its world, you can't help but marvel at its art, deep in the frigid mountains to the ruins of a city long abandoned, and you're drawn further in by the awesome music that it emits. It truly tells an interesting tale.You are Born. A being that escaped from the Void to see and live a life for yourself. As you traverse Nihilumbra's world, you come across various 'colors', which act as both your tools and your weapons. For instance, Blue is Ice, allowing your character to either move quicker and jump further or to allow your enemies to slip and slide off a ledge to be trapped or to their untimely doom. Each color that you get are often used in conjunction with one another to help solve the game's many puzzles. Puzzles that I found very appealing, and interesting, some of them simple, some of them more complex. It's all about how you analyze the situation and how you yourself are going to utilize what has been given. With a solid control scheme and responsiveness, the game didn't feel it was trying to work against the player, which is crucial for a puzzle platformer.When you start, it gives you a 'Story-esque' tutorial, here is where you learn how to play, what to expect, and how Born and everything around you reacts to your actions. It was interesting actually, and didn't feel as if the game was holding my hand, but rather an introduction. It was a nice touch by developers. After the 'story' as been completed, you are far from being finished. Now, you must right the wrongs that you have done, and this is where the real fun begins. It was a lot of fun figuring out the puzzles, and after completing each one, the accomplishment was indeed satisfying.Overall, it's a game that is well worth its price. With an overall great infrastructure, and charm, Nihilumbra has easily become one of my favorites. I highly recommend it to those who enjoys puzzle platformers, or to any gamer in general. It's that easy to pick up and play, and easily be drawn into its fantastical world.

												This is a fun platformer game with an incredible gameplay idea. You gain powers, each power being a different colour. Blue for example can make things slide/go faster, like ice. There are many colours, and the combinations provide for interesting answers to how you must progress throughout stages. There are enemies that are quite tricky to avoid, plus the void from which the protagonist was born will chase after you at the last level of every stage.Apart from the gameplay, the narration is great, and many of the music tracks are wonderful as well. The enemy design is high quality as well, though some of the background art could be better. The main story is just challenging enough to keep you interested, but after you're done, the Void Mode unlocks and it's.... so tough! I'll probably spend the next two years trying to finish it.All in all, this is a really interesting game, though if you don't think you're going to bother with the Void Mode, it might be better to wait for a sale since the main game is about 3 hours long.

Posted: January 24, 2016
												Nihilumbra first appears as yet another 2D puzzle platformer in a long line of indie games trying to follow the successes of Braid and Limbo from years back.  Once the game begins, it’s quite clear those assumptions are not without reason, but diving deeper reveals a much bolder game with grander ambitions than the typical modern sidescroller.Video Review - 


YouTube™ Video: Nihilumbra (PC) - #1 - Frozen mountains 

			Views: 113		

			Pack your bags! Get moving! The void is after us. Let's GTFO of here before it catches us! Subscribe for new videos every week!		

		The player controls a creature named “Born” as it escapes an empty void into the physical world. As Born progresses, a narrator will explain the futility of the whole affair. The narrator insists the void will relentlessly chase Born down as the “the void must be one.” The narrator argues the world is harsh and doesn’t care what the fate of Born will be. The narrator repeats Born is not a part of the physical world and cannot live there. Born is nothing. It’s all pointless. Born will die. Nihilumbra, as its name suggests, is a game about Nihilism – a philosophy asserting the meaninglessness of life. 	The message is presented in a brutally heavy handed way. It has the subtlety of a hammer slamming on a nail. Perhaps some will find this off-putting, but the decision to forgo nuance results in a gut wrenching emotional conflict between Born and the narrator. As Born moves through the world in spite of the harsh rhetoric, the narrator can be seen as Born’s internal doubt. Progressing through the world feels like an accomplishment, not only for overcoming obstacles, but for overcoming the narrator’s negativity. Eventually, the narrator will admit Born is putting up a good fight. One of the best scenes is early on, when a set of obstacles tests Born’s physical abilities. Born is not strong enough, nor quick enough, but maybe - maybe Born is smart enough. 	The Nihilistic philosophy of the narrator is constantly undermined throughout the adventure.  The narrator will present a point in their favor, and quickly offer a counterpoint, countering that point, and then countering it again. The narrator argues with itself, and can be seen as a debate inside Born’s head. While the always in pursuit void is a threat, doubt and anxiety within Born are the central conflicts. 	The narrator, while maintaining the end is nigh, provides tons of encouragement to push Born and the player onwards. It offers assurances just as much as it offers doubt.  It’s never an unlikable presence and more often than not feels like a good friend and ally. As Born comes across and absorbs elemental powers, the narrator will instruct on how to use them. The elements themselves are typical of this type of game. There is slippery ice, bouncy grass, and destructive lava. Sand and Electricity are the stand outs. With Electricity, the player can create currents sending power to contraptions like elevators and turrets. Sand is the most versatile of them all, allowing the player to slow enemies, withstand fierce winds, stick to walls, and silence footsteps. The narrator will also take the time to explain various enemies around the world. Some chase, some shoot, some will erase elemental powers, and other just suck … quite literally. 	The game is masterfully paced, presenting these abilities one at a time, but not spending very much time with a single element on its own. The game follows a formula where it teaches an element in a safe tutorial, then asks the player to use the element by itself, and finally tasks the player with using the element in conjunction with previously learned abilities. There is always a feeling of progress and of learning something new with every scenario. Again, there is nothing completely unique about the gameplay, but it is well executed.	The only blemishes to the game are tedious chase sequences in which the Void has found Born and attempts to reabsorb them. These moments are used as an equivalent of boss battles, happening at the end of an act and requiring mastery of that acts new mechanics. Nihilumbra’s puzzles are clever, but are never a challenge. As such, the problem with these battles is twofold. Often the puzzles are too easy to solve, leaving Born to wait on the camera to move forward. Alternatively, the full breadth of a puzzle isn’t unveiled quick enough and can’t be completed in a timely fashion resulting in a frustrating death. These sequences are only a small portion of the game, but are definitely its weakest points.	The games real strengths rarely come from the gameplay by itself, but rather how the powers, enemies, and puzzles blend beautifully with the story being told. As Born gains new abilities, it becomes clear they are becoming more attached to the world around them than they are to the void giving chase. The narrator notes, Born was nothing when it left the void, but through these learned abilities has definitely become something. With this revelation, the game shifts from being a dramatic depression factory into a somewhat uplifting criticism of Nihilism. 	What Nihilumbra does is nothing extraordinary, but it wraps itself in a protective blanket of rich atmosphere and tastefully direct writing perfect for the moody teenager in all of us. Its story and gameplay meld seamlessly with excellent music and art to create a completely cohesive vison throughout its entirety. Nihilumbra knows what it is, isn’t ashamed of it, and preforms with a high grade of quality.

												Nihilumbra started off as an iPhone game that I loved and enjoyed for its story telling. It is like a metroidvania puzzle game that is linear. There are no branching paths like a true metroidvania but story is of more importance than gameplay. That being said the gameplay is well crafted and all the puzzles are solvable with minimal intrusion, this is not like early point and click adventure game puzzles but more of an actio-adventure sort in 2D. The Steam version has an added art gallery and full voice over. THe voice over is nice but is not needed, though having played both versions it was a nice addition, but I still think the voice over work is more like a director's commentary and shouldn't be heard the first time around. It is one of my favorite indie games to come out in the past year or so.So yes, buy this game for the experience. It's better than Limbo, and about as good (if easier) than Braid.

Posted: May 28, 2015
												Get it if it's on sale.Overall, not bad. But it seems like the creators saw these beautiful, story-rich art games catching on and wanted to make one so. very. desperately. The only thing the over-prevalent story can claim as its own is a narrator that won't shut up, telling you what you should feel on just about every screen, ultimately resulting in you feeling nothing. It doesn't help that the writing is poorly translated, and that the lone voice actor dutifully reads through typos as if they make as much sense to him as anything else in the script. (Honestly, given the fact that the guy had to say things like: "Red possesses the power of fire" that seems likely.) Someone missed the memo that games like this should omit text and voice acting entirely, unless it's borderline poetry.Now that that's out of the way, other artistic elements flourish. Honestly, I bought the game because of how gorgeous the screenshots looked, and it didn't disappoint visually all the way through. The animation, in particular, is extremely detailed, and it seems like every time you watch your character move, you see something you didn't notice before. All the backgrounds are equally pretty. The orchestral soundtrack is utterly fantastic, and the most surprising thing about the game (yes, it has an orchestral soundtrack). I just wish the developer had had the wisdom to let these elements speak for themselves.I know I'm mentioning the gameplay last, but personally, while it may have been easy, I thought the powers were a lot of fun to play with, and the mechanics for how they worked together were pretty well thought out. I haven't started Void mode yet, but I've heard it's when the game actually gets difficult, and that the 3 hour campaign is really just an extended tutorial. Honestly, I think it's a good format for a game with memorable mechanics, and this one has them. I'd love to see the game take advantage of the green and brown powers to make some insane platforming sequences. We'll have to see whether I'm disappointed or not later on.

Posted: January 9, 2015
												The playthrough can be divided into two main stages. Casual - ~2h main story mode where you learn about your abilities and about puzzles. There is narration, feels, thoughts etc. When you finish this mode the game unlocks the "void mode", which is a more difficult mode which tests your understanding of the mechanics. Progressing in the void mode unlocks more stuff in the art gallery, which actually is a nice reward. The art is a strong side of this game. I'm glad you can even see designer scetches when you unlock that.Thoughts:I wasn't very comfortable with the controls (and the mechanics). Initial momentum is very important, you don't get much control mid-air.Levels are divided into screens. I get a feeling that this decision was brought up very late, as beating some screens requires speeding up from an area on another screen. I wish this game used the classic side-scrolling model.The narrator began to annoy me a little after some time (he sounded a little monotonic). Also after respawning at a checkpoint a few times the narrator reads the same lines every time, which is also getting annoying after a few times.Art is an important aspect of games like this. Progressing unlocks more entries in the art gallery, which in my opinion is a good reward (there are also achievements, which add replayability value).While the story mode is beatable in short time, I'm sure the void mode will take a lot more time to beat as it is more puzzle-and-mechanics based.So, should you get it?It's an interesting position. Made me a little emotional actually. The art and music fit well together. The narrator says some things that actually make you think about life and death a little. If you're looking for something like that - go for it. If you're looking for a challenging platformer then I'd recommend something else. This game takes away some control from the player.

												I can appreciate and understand the message they wish to convey, however, that being said, they take a typical approach, with very little thought put into its design. The art, although stylized, felt rushed, the story which tried to be engaging, was both unoriginal and rushed. I found the puzzles to be very predictable and hardly engaging, There was no real rewarding feeling you do not identify with born and the narrator at times is too slow, and can even just be an annoyance. Very short game, with poor gameplay and predictable story, a great example of what not to do in game design. I can clearly see its inspirations and its overall goal however the approach taken was wrong. The ending felt almost like a "what" moment, where in teh beginning it was eluded too, tehn forgotten, then brought back. If youre buying this solely for the story mode, then dont waste your time, overall a 6/10, but for the price, those are my only complaints.

												All I have to say about this game is that I dont really like platformer games but I love this game. I played it all the way through in 2 days which, at its short length isnt that hard. But the void mode which is unlocked after that will keep you busy for a while after that. This game is beautiful with the different colors. And the narrator was a nice touch keeping the game from feeling too lonely which it would have been without that and left me wanting more of his voice. The story of the game is simple but deep at the same time, if you want to think in it too much. Overall this is an amazing game and you should stop reading my ramblings and go buy it already!

Posted: January 3, 2014
												"Beautifun Games" is right.  This is a true hidden gem of a platformer/puzzler with it's unique art-style, nice/soothing soundtrack, and challenging puzzles.  Watching the trailer should be enough reason to want to purchase this game.  Some reviewers have given this game some flack for it's dark tones/negative narrator.  It is deeper than what is being said by the narrator though.  After the main story there is a "Void mode" which is MUCH more challenging than the first playthrough.  You are sure to enjoy this game if you enjoyed LIMBO, Trine, Braid, The Swapper, etc.  Looking forward to see what Beutifun Games comes out with next.

												Nihilumbra is a mix between a puzzle game, and a platformer game. It has a pretty straight forward story, but it's still nice. The gameplay mechanics are great, and forget about it being a mobile game prior to its release on Steam. I didn't even realize it was first a mobile game until after I beat it. Throughout the game you will gain new abilities which can work together to solve puzzles. There are a few enemy types, all of which come with there own strengths and weaknesses. Don't worry about the game being "too easy," because things get more difficult down the road.Long story short, it's totally worth the money. I got it on sale, but I would definitely have payed full price for this experience.

Posted: January 5, 2015
												Nihilumbra is a 2D platformer with an extremely compelling art style and story.Story: Without spoiling too much in Nihilumbra you play as Born a being from the void and you set out to find your purpose while the void tries to stop you. In short this game has a great story and I encourage that you see for yourself.Gameplay: Nihilumbra is a 2D platformer were you must use colors to your advantage. Each color has a unique property that you can use to your advantage whether it's going through terrain, avoiding enemies or solving puzzles. In this game there is no way to kill enemies yourself until later in the game you also need to use your enviroment to help you. Using colors in my opinion was a great way to expand the depth in the gameplay and make it much less simple but not too complicated.Presentation: The art style of this game is beautiful. It really shows difference between the different levels you advance through and uses a wide range of colors. Not to mention that in this version there is now an art gallery where you can look at concept art, sketchs and level designs.Is it Good? There is one complaint I have about this game and thats how short it is if you play it fast it could be less then 3 hours of gameplay (not including Void mode). But besides that this hidden gem of an indie game is worth buying.

Posted: February 4, 2015
												regardless of what you say, narrator, that blob of void is not a hehow could you---this is where steam's binary 'do you recommend this' metric fails for me since it has too many flaws to be a no questions asked buy but i wouldn't completely write it off.the balance is weird, with the main campaign being very easy and feeling like an extended tutorial at times, while the new game plus 'void mode' is basically impossible (i never got past the first screen). i love games with narrators, but the narrator is second rate and better as text than as a voice. the asthethic and feel of this game is really good (those monsters <3) , but the art assets themselves are pretty mediocre, feeling a little too 'default photoshop brush' fuzzy around the edges. i wrote this review like 3 months after i finished the game so i don't remember the ending all that well, whoops! still, i enjoyed playing this game and am interested in what this dev does next

Posted: March 7, 2015
												The story is a terrifying, dark, twisted, tragic and sad journey, but delivered in the most subtle and gentle tone imagineable. I suspect some sense of spirituality or religious material as some of the inspiration or perhaps the basis of some elements. Yet, I percieve this more as a metaphysical mirror of the nature of life, death and reality, presented in a way that wouldn't frighten children;  even if the subject matter is a little too deep for them. The somber soundtrack suits the mood of the story very well. I don't think this game misrepresented anything in the description, however, I was a little disappointed. I don't think it's a bad game at all, just not really for me. Also, really short and extremely concise in every aspect.I am recommending this review based on the fact that had I really looked at the game descriptions, I might not have gotten it, but there were really alot of positive reviews, probably by alot of people who like very casual games.When they say, "casual," they really mean, "casual." This game really has little to no challenge at all. It has some very simple and very basic mechanics coupled with unusual and original devices, but that I find has been implemented to a very limited degree as far as challenge and stimulation are concerned. It's cute and fun in a way. I only mention that because I find this game to be perfect for any child that can handle simple game mechanics.I don't dislike this game, but it's really too moderate for me. I think the premise deserves a much darker tone, more intense atmosphere, and much more philosophical literature. I think if you like children's tales and really casual and simple games, then I do recommend it.

Posted: January 2, 2014
												Some games are just fun, some tell a good story, and others can only be called works of art. Nihilumbra manages to be all three at once. The gameplay is satisfying as it blends tricky yet manageable platforming with puzzles involving physics-altering pigments. The story is charming at first, since you can not help but cheer for the little blob of life who has just been Born of nothingness, then slowly becomes more tragic as he is forced to bring death into the world around him simply by the act of surviving. Nihilumbra is also a beatiful artistic piece, sporting deep, ponderous themes and striking visuals both in the background and in the foreground. All these factors grip you and hold you so that you do not want to stop playing until it's done. I can't say for sure whether this game changed me as a person, but it certainly made a powerful impression on me. This is a wholehearted recommendation from one very impressed player.

Posted: January 3, 2014
												"Beautifun Games" is right.  This is a true hidden gem of a platformer/puzzler with it's unique art-style, nice/soothing soundtrack, and challenging puzzles.  Watching the trailer should be enough reason to want to purchase this game.  Some reviewers have given this game some flack for it's dark tones/negative narrator.  It is deeper than what is being said by the narrator though.  After the main story there is a "Void mode" which is MUCH more challenging than the first playthrough.  You are sure to enjoy this game if you enjoyed LIMBO, Trine, Braid, The Swapper, etc.  Looking forward to see what Beutifun Games comes out with next.

Posted: January 8, 2014
												If you like more relaxed or strategic games, this is one for you! The game takes place in the void and many parts of the earth. A small black blob of "nothingness" escapes The Void and is trying to find out who he is, what he is, and where he belongs while the void is trying to capture him and bring him back. He doesnt understand the world but as the game progresses he begins to learn. The narrations are cool and in my perspective the narrator is like "life", always trying to bring him down and make him feel like he isnt good enough but he always proves the narrator wrong. Its fairly easy, except for a few parts that seem to have no soloution but once you figure it out its fine. There are parts closer to the end of each "world" which are more fast paced and challenging but if you have a friend with you so you can share the controls and do two things at once, it may be beneficial for you when passing the ends of each level. You should definitly download this game if it sounds like something your interested in, but hurry...The Void is Coming for you. :)

Posted: January 5, 2014
												Now I do like this game I really do, but it has some quirks that I myself found annoying one being the narrator during the whole adventure. From begining to end this narrator will try and tell you something about the world your in. At first this is fine but then it  quickly becomes annoying when he does it for every other room transition and then he tries to tell you how to feel  "you feel sadness" then im just sitting here thinking to my self while squinting my eyes "dont tell me how to feel, Mr narrator man". Also I was unsure what kind of narrator he is, whether he was the character experiencing the world or  all knowing omnipresent void in the begining of the game. It became more confusing when the narrator switches from helping me by giving me hints to then belittling me for destroying the world. My point is that the game could of used alot less narrative or at least a more consistent one.Now I got two more design nit picks that I have to get off my chest. Although the worlds are beautiful I felt that they were marred by fact we see gunturrets propped in the middle of this beautiful forest. I feel like the designers of Nihilumbra were going make a platformer with a much more syfy setting but changed their mind near the end and couldn't redo all of the objects. Now the last thing would have to be what I suppose you could call a "boss" which is when the void comes from the left side of the screen which provides the sense of urgency, but what bothered me is i couldn't run from void until it begun moving forward. So here I am trying to move to the right but I cant becuase the void it too slow. so im just sitting to the right  waiting for the void to catch up so I can progress which took sense of urgency right out of the whole situation. If they maybe just allowed me to move to the right without restriction, they could of sped the void and made me feel the urgency that they wanted to make me feel.All in all a good puzzle platformer game that I felt had more potential and could been something great. I wouldn't say not get this game for 10$ but it might intrest you to wait for a sale.

Posted: January 5, 2014
												Really amazing indie game. Nice nihillistic story with enjoyable storytelling and animation. It's more puzzle solving game rather than platformer at least the first part. In the first part you collect collors in five different worlds. Each color gives you some special ability like you can paint red color on the floor to burn monsters. After finishing the game, which will happen pretty soon because it's quite short and easy, you will unlock challenge mode. In this mode you can go through previous worlds (in any order) which are now a bit modified to provide more difficult brain teasers and rexlex & timing abilities. Problem is that it's not very well ballanced and some levels are really difficult. See, difficulty is not increasing regularly but it's somehow random. At the end all puzzles and challenges are possible to handle ballancing on boundary where it can get bit too frustrating especially if you're not skilled in this type of games. After beating this mode you will unlock special "Secret Language" bonus which gives the game brand new replayability and chance to enjoy something untraditional and funny. To sum up, it has some pros and some cons but overall for 2.50€ in sale it's great deal you shouldn't miss.

Posted: June 2, 2015
												Fun, easy to learn/difficult to master, and rather short, Nihilumbra's story mode can probably be finished in a single sitting. Controls are easy and intuitive, and powers are doled out at regular intervals. Many of the puzzles are quite clever, though to be blunt the most fun ones are extremely front-loaded. The art style and music are absolutely gorgeous, and though simple, the clear aesthetic unity and crispness puts many other games in its price range to shame. The game only suffers from two problems, but they are irksome: 1) Even in story ("easy") mode, there are moments that are just plain unforgiving. Many puzzles are more accurately described as "die so you see the mechanic, respawn, use knowledge get through mechanic, then die to next mechanic, repeat." Essentially savescumming as progression. This isn't Planescape: Torment where death was used to solve puzzles, it's just a way to pad out the game's length. There's a very noticeable drop-off in players who have the level 1 and 2 completed achievements; a fact that coincides noticeably with the first die-through-it puzzle. 2) The script seems like something written by a teenager going through a goth phase. and is narrated by someone extremely doped up on sleep meds. If you enjoy the slow, monotonous, repetitive naming of emotions rather than any actual content that would invoke those feelings, this may be up your alley. For most people, though, it's most likely simply to bring back repressed memories of terrible college creative-writing papers. You remember the one guy who always told everyone how deep and underappreciated he was despite not having done anything memorable? That's this game's script. That said, the actual gameplay is generally fantastic. At least until you unlock Void ("hard") mode by beating the story. There's a reason that roughly 1/6th the people who beat the game have even a single Void level clear achievement. Void Mode is die-through-it on steroids, and will literally kill you within seconds of spawning on the very first stage of the first level. Up until you get to Void, however, it's a fun, mostly casual game that anyone with a fondness for platformers will enjoy. Art: 10/10Sound: 10/10Writing: 4/10Gameplay: 7/10Overall: 8/10Definitely worth the buy, especially considering how cheap it is.

Posted: May 28, 2015
												Get it if it's on sale.Overall, not bad. But it seems like the creators saw these beautiful, story-rich art games catching on and wanted to make one so. very. desperately. The only thing the over-prevalent story can claim as its own is a narrator that won't shut up, telling you what you should feel on just about every screen, ultimately resulting in you feeling nothing. It doesn't help that the writing is poorly translated, and that the lone voice actor dutifully reads through typos as if they make as much sense to him as anything else in the script. (Honestly, given the fact that the guy had to say things like: "Red possesses the power of fire" that seems likely.) Someone missed the memo that games like this should omit text and voice acting entirely, unless it's borderline poetry.Now that that's out of the way, other artistic elements flourish. Honestly, I bought the game because of how gorgeous the screenshots looked, and it didn't disappoint visually all the way through. The animation, in particular, is extremely detailed, and it seems like every time you watch your character move, you see something you didn't notice before. All the backgrounds are equally pretty. The orchestral soundtrack is utterly fantastic, and the most surprising thing about the game (yes, it has an orchestral soundtrack). I just wish the developer had had the wisdom to let these elements speak for themselves.I know I'm mentioning the gameplay last, but personally, while it may have been easy, I thought the powers were a lot of fun to play with, and the mechanics for how they worked together were pretty well thought out. I haven't started Void mode yet, but I've heard it's when the game actually gets difficult, and that the 3 hour campaign is really just an extended tutorial. Honestly, I think it's a good format for a game with memorable mechanics, and this one has them. I'd love to see the game take advantage of the green and brown powers to make some insane platforming sequences. We'll have to see whether I'm disappointed or not later on.

												Good:Well-programmed physics and platformingSeemingly creative solutionsPhilosophical storyBad:Normal mode way too easy Hard mode a little too difficultAnnoying narrative voiceSolutions may be "creative," but are linear neverthelessNihilumbra throws you into a sidescrolling physics platformer with no native gamepad support, though it makes more sense to use a mouse for painting surfaces specific functioning colors.  The story is semi-interesting revolving teaching you the surface of basic nihilism based on ideas of a consuming and ending Void.  The really big issue for the game is the very annoying ominous voice that is sometimes directive, encouraging, degrading, and overall contradictive--it would have been a strength to remove some narrative and the voice acting all together.Short even with two modes.  Enjoy only for a low price.

Posted: December 24, 2015
												Nihilumbra is a nice little way to spend the afternoon. It's nothing truly incredible, the visuals don't really have a unified style, the environments are a bit samey and the narration seems forced, but in the end, I enjoyed it.Nihilumbra has a fairly unique set of mechanics that make for decent puzzles, the character sprite looks incredible, and there's something very original about the story, becoming more introspective and character-focused than I ever imagined it would be. If I'm honest, I expected this to be sort of a lazy indie game clone: Bastion had narration, Limbo had bleak environments and silouhettes, Tag had paint that covers surfaces and alters their attributes, but there's still something unique and special about Nihilumbra, and that's the story. Even though the story centers around (generously speaking) only one character, and even despite the cliched appearance, I was left satisfied nonetheless.

												I bought this game at summer sale and just beat the Story Mode. I actually decided to get this since it was cheap and I love Haunter from Pokemon...since the artwork was great I didn't care how great as a game Nihilumbra is.I, however, hereby am proud to say that this game has betrayed me. Apart from the one place in the Boss Stage, where you have to jump at the right place the first time, everything wasn't that hard and hell-a-lot fun. It makes you twist your brain; and it is worth every penny. And the main character is so cute! His/Her every reaction is...well I don't know how to explain but it is cute. MEGA cute. Like this guy sneezes when they are cold. And more. OMG. Why did you guys have to put those faces in, dear creators? I'm now in love.Anyways on personal note, I'm happy that the Boss representation wasn't the one on Bottom Left of the concept art. I may not have been able to continue the game out of fear if that happened. I like the ones on the right...top and bottom. :P  But now that I beat the game I think the final decision is the greatest.

Posted: December 14, 2014
												Nihilumbra is a game that at first glance seems a little too inspired by Limbo for some, but upon further inspection is a game that creates its own unique world and atmosphere.One of the aspects that sets this game apart from Limbo is its narration. The voiceover never completely explains certain parts of the story, which keeps a certain mystery around the game's world, and sometimes may make the player consider what side the narrator is on. Subtitles are set to be always on, and are integrated into the game's environment so people can still read the story if the narrator annoys them that much, though I personally enjoyed the storytelling.The game has a reasonable difficulty curve for the main story, though there were a few puzzles that were a little more difficult than someone would suspect at only 1 or 2 points in the journey. Nihilumbra also features a challenge mode similar to Super Meat Boy called "Void Mode", which has every level from the main story but more difficult and without narration, effectively doubling the game's levels from 40 to 80.Void Mode provides some replay value to Nihilumbra, and the puzzles range from a worthy challenge to a bit vague. Certain solutions have no origin in story mode, such as bouncing and sliding a crate on the ground between two points so it can hit multiple switches, and will probably result in a player looking up the answer. However, the majority of puzzles have been somewhat reasonable, with some requiring excellent timing and others utilizing planning in advance.This game is a welcome addition to my library, especially when I purchased it at only $2 during a sale. I look forward to the remaining challenges this game can provide. FYI: For those curious, the Linux version, which I'm using, works, but the achievements unlocked in-game do not sync with Steam without some work. A solution is mentioned by someone here: http://www.reddit.com/r/linux_gaming/comments/1u2v4r/couple_of_tips_for_nihilumbra_players_on_64bit/which also links to a dev post on Steam forums for any necessary further explanation.

Anyone who enjoys platformers, puzzles, or just indie games in general should definitely pick this up.

Posted: December 29, 2015
												Challenging, atmospheric, meaningful and immersive; all that describes Nihilumbra. Many know this game as an iOS port, but it is definitely best played on PC. You play as a piece of void, who craves to seek the world beyond darkness -- and this game really delivers the emotions of the voidling through the narration of the 'voice inside your head'. It is quite short, however, but very thought provoking.Consider the first time you finish the game as your tutorial for the challenge mode that comes next: The Void Mode. So the game never stops challenging you with harder and harder levels.A great buy, especially if you purchase on a sale.

Posted: January 24, 2016
												Nihilumbra first appears as yet another 2D puzzle platformer in a long line of indie games trying to follow the successes of Braid and Limbo from years back.  Once the game begins, it’s quite clear those assumptions are not without reason, but diving deeper reveals a much bolder game with grander ambitions than the typical modern sidescroller.Video Review - 


YouTube™ Video: Nihilumbra - Andar's Judgment 

			Views: 24		

			Nihilumbra first appears as yet another 2D puzzle platformer in a long line of indie games trying to follow the successes of Braid and Limbo from years back.		

		The player controls a creature named “Born” as it escapes an empty void into the physical world. As Born progresses, a narrator will explain the futility of the whole affair. The narrator insists the void will relentlessly chase Born down as the “the void must be one.” The narrator argues the world is harsh and doesn’t care what the fate of Born will be. The narrator repeats Born is not a part of the physical world and cannot live there. Born is nothing. It’s all pointless. Born will die. Nihilumbra, as its name suggests, is a game about Nihilism – a philosophy asserting the meaninglessness of life. 	The message is presented in a brutally heavy handed way. It has the subtlety of a hammer slamming on a nail. Perhaps some will find this off-putting, but the decision to forgo nuance results in a gut wrenching emotional conflict between Born and the narrator. As Born moves through the world in spite of the harsh rhetoric, the narrator can be seen as Born’s internal doubt. Progressing through the world feels like an accomplishment, not only for overcoming obstacles, but for overcoming the narrator’s negativity. Eventually, the narrator will admit Born is putting up a good fight. One of the best scenes is early on, when a set of obstacles tests Born’s physical abilities. Born is not strong enough, nor quick enough, but maybe - maybe Born is smart enough. 	The Nihilistic philosophy of the narrator is constantly undermined throughout the adventure.  The narrator will present a point in their favor, and quickly offer a counterpoint, countering that point, and then countering it again. The narrator argues with itself, and can be seen as a debate inside Born’s head. While the always in pursuit void is a threat, doubt and anxiety within Born are the central conflicts. 	The narrator, while maintaining the end is nigh, provides tons of encouragement to push Born and the player onwards. It offers assurances just as much as it offers doubt.  It’s never an unlikable presence and more often than not feels like a good friend and ally. As Born comes across and absorbs elemental powers, the narrator will instruct on how to use them. The elements themselves are typical of this type of game. There is slippery ice, bouncy grass, and destructive lava. Sand and Electricity are the stand outs. With Electricity, the player can create currents sending power to contraptions like elevators and turrets. Sand is the most versatile of them all, allowing the player to slow enemies, withstand fierce winds, stick to walls, and silence footsteps. The narrator will also take the time to explain various enemies around the world. Some chase, some shoot, some will erase elemental powers, and other just suck … quite literally. 	The game is masterfully paced, presenting these abilities one at a time, but not spending very much time with a single element on its own. The game follows a formula where it teaches an element in a safe tutorial, then asks the player to use the element by itself, and finally tasks the player with using the element in conjunction with previously learned abilities. There is always a feeling of progress and of learning something new with every scenario. Again, there is nothing completely unique about the gameplay, but it is well executed.	The only blemishes to the game are tedious chase sequences in which the Void has found Born and attempts to reabsorb them. These moments are used as an equivalent of boss battles, happening at the end of an act and requiring mastery of that acts new mechanics. Nihilumbra’s puzzles are clever, but are never a challenge. As such, the problem with these battles is twofold. Often the puzzles are too easy to solve, leaving Born to wait on the camera to move forward. Alternatively, the full breadth of a puzzle isn’t unveiled quick enough and can’t be completed in a timely fashion resulting in a frustrating death. These sequences are only a small portion of the game, but are definitely its weakest points.	The games real strengths rarely come from the gameplay by itself, but rather how the powers, enemies, and puzzles blend beautifully with the story being told. As Born gains new abilities, it becomes clear they are becoming more attached to the world around them than they are to the void giving chase. The narrator notes, Born was nothing when it left the void, but through these learned abilities has definitely become something. With this revelation, the game shifts from being a dramatic depression factory into a somewhat uplifting criticism of Nihilism. 	What Nihilumbra does is nothing extraordinary, but it wraps itself in a protective blanket of rich atmosphere and tastefully direct writing perfect for the moody teenager in all of us. Its story and gameplay meld seamlessly with excellent music and art to create a completely cohesive vison throughout its entirety. Nihilumbra knows what it is, isn’t ashamed of it, and preforms with a high grade of quality.

Posted: December 29, 2015
												Challenging, atmospheric, meaningful and immersive; all that describes Nihilumbra. Many know this game as an iOS port, but it is definitely best played on PC. You play as a piece of void, who craves to seek the world beyond darkness -- and this game really delivers the emotions of the voidling through the narration of the 'voice inside your head'. It is quite short, however, but very thought provoking.Consider the first time you finish the game as your tutorial for the challenge mode that comes next: The Void Mode. So the game never stops challenging you with harder and harder levels.A great buy, especially if you purchase on a sale.

Posted: January 5, 2016
												Absolutely one of the most beautiful 2D platforming games ever made. I originally found this by accident on the iTunes App Store, and it was one of the best purchases I've ever made. As soon as I saw that it was available on Steam, I obviously purchased it in a heartbeat. The graphics, music and story are unprecedented, and really make you question the world you live in and the way you live your life. What really brings this masterpiece to life though, in my opinion, is the musical score. It is so emotional, I can almost hear the composer's thoughts as he brought notes to paper. To me, gaming has always been an art, and if you believe that too, you should purchase this game and experience what it has to offer.PS: There's a surprize at the end!

Posted: July 10, 2014
												Very beatiful piece of art. The first time you go through it, it is mostly a story telling game, and i simply loved living this adventure. Very deep. Another good aspect is the fantasy it relases, you have to wisely use your "colors", which have different powers, to go through the game. In normal mode it isn't that difficult, but in "void mode", unlocked once finishing the game, heck, it becomes really difficult! The art works are fascinating and catching, the narrator voice is like your only fellow in your odissey, the music and the atmosphere are really involving and will make you want to get to the end of the game, the end of the story, the end of the suffering?! In conclusion, i'd reccomend this game to ones who like challenging puzzle games, or good story telling ones

Posted: December 13, 2016
												A game about overcoming an existential life crisis with heavy usage of art motifs for emotion? SOLD! :DNihilumbra is a unique indie 2D platformer/puzzle game in which you play as an awakened consciousness from the Void that has decided to escape from the dreary and desolate darkness and start life anew, traveling across vast landscapes while the Void lingers slightly behind in pursuit. You, as the Void Creature, traverse across numerous unique and beautiful landscapes to discover your purpose in life while solving puzzles to progress further. The game's light platforming segments are made into unique puzzles based around various powers you acquire from different colored flowers, each with its own special ability and suiting to the environment. If anything can be properly said about Nihilumbra, is that it does it's tone WONDERFULLY. As you travel across the land, your exploits and thoughts are told by a wisened narrator that offers his thoughts (or rather, narrates your own in second-person fashion) on every instance you find yourself in. The game's atmosphere is finely split between three moods: Wonder, somber, and fear. Every new area you enter, you find yourself experiencing thoughts of wonder and curiosity, amazed at every little thing, from the embracing green of the leaves to the harsh red of fire. However, the mood shifts to somber once you realize that the Void, having been chasing after you on your journey for leaving, will come soon and consume the land. And finally, when the Void shows up, intensity is raked up to twenty, and you are in a state of panic as the narrator continues his tirade about hopelessness and inevitability, some part of you desperatly clinging to the idea that he is wrong and you can prove it!!!... Wow, that got a little outta hand there, didn't it?Well! Anyway, Nihilumbra is an artistically pleasing game, good on the eyes, good on the ears, good on the gameplay, and good looking in your game library. I give this game a positive recommendation and a 8/10 rating. Plus, there's always Void mode to play post game, if you're so inclined for the challenge...

Posted: December 20, 2016
												Ah, Nihilumbra, another one of those "Cute" games that comments philosophically on the nature of life, the universe, and everything. Yes, a lot of games do this, but I have never been so attached to a character as I have been to Born, so much wanted to see this character grow, and so wanted everything to be okay for the little mite. You really kind of have to put your own spin on the character by nature of what it is, and that's pretty different from most games like this I've seen.The story is that you (Born) are a shadow being from the Void - the Nothingness, that is - and you, curious about the world outside the Void, break free from it into the world of... Something. Quickly, you learn to become and adapt in this environment, changing it, loving it, only for the Void to come after you time and again, trying to reclaim you. The way Born navigates his environs is through elemental magic of a sort, painting elements onto the environs to solve physics puzzles in a way somewhat reminiscent of Okami/Okamiden. Of course, Okami/Okamiden never left me a crying disaster over a shadow creature just trying to make his way in the world, because puppies generally try not to hurt your heart when they make mistakes. The monsters in the game are terrifyingly designed and (yes I know my reviews say this a lot) really do look like something out of a Lovecraft story. Try looking at a Crawlaggar and NOT seeing something that could reasonably pass as a Hound of the Tindalos, I dare you, especially when it comes chasing after you in packs from off-screen...That said, this charming game is not everyone's cup of tea - there is a New Game Plus mode after the end of the normal game, a sort of "B Adventure" where you go back through the levels fixing what the Void has destroyed, and it is ABSOLUTELY BRUTALLY HARD. I'm serious, I consider myself a puzzle buff and a fan of rogue-style difficulty, but this is even too much for me. Split-second timing, rather unfair jumps, trial and error, and using elements to deflect bullets into incredibly tough series of enemies - they're all here, often during the chapter-end chases, and they will bend you over a table and go in dry. I am not kidding here, the New Game Plus of this game reaches unprecidented levels of Guide Dang It at points, and that's not even counting the various achievements that aren't related to gameplay itself! I genuinely needed a walkthrough to even make it to the end, and even that was difficult when you look at some of the absolute bull-hocky that this game expects you to do in New Game Plus. To compound that, Born's hitbox sometimes plays oddly with certain enemies - like the Vacuumore - where even being two feet away from the enemy's maw is enough to kill you. This also appears to occur with boxes and spikes on some occasions. I suspect this is a bit of a glitch or oversight, and the game maker did not intend to make the hitbox quite so sensitive, in which case - please fix this, it makes the game quite difficult for the wrong reasons.At the same time, IMHO, the normal game is almost too easy, with obvious solutions to fairly obvious puzzles. Yes, it gets very clever with them - using the bounce power to ricochet bullets, using the sticky power to stick enemies to walls and ceilings (which is freaking hilarious to watch because they flail around), etc. However, generally any time you need speed, you used the slippery power, making electronics work uses the electronic power, etc. Obvious problem + Obvious power = Obvious solution, and I wish that there was more use of mixing of powers to get to a solution as the New Game Plus does. So, between the main game being too easy, and New Game Plus being too hard (but not impossible), couldn't there have been a bit more of a transition between the two? Maybe like, just add more monsters instead of more difficult puzzles, or add more puzzles but not more monsters? Then you could have an easy, medium, and hard mode for those who wanted to play around with the powers and use new and more interesting power combinations to reach their goals, and you could have had the B Adventure be tougher without being so tough it made me tear my hair out in frustration. At the very least, you could have cut down on the number of timing-sensitive puzzles that are near freaking impossible; there's a difference between Nintendo Hard and Frustrating.All in all, I do still like this game, a lot, and find it difficult to hate. The scenery and general idea behind it is gorgeous, I love playing Pseudo-Okami with the powers, and obtaining each power was a true pleasure and very satisfying. Burning things with the fire power is amazingly fun, and the puzzles are pretty clever all things considered. I would recommend this game, but only if you like physics platform-puzzlers with a tough streak in its New Game Plus, because seriously - that second half makes you WORK for its achievements...

												Nihilumbra is a fun game about a creature, Born, born from "The Void," a primordial entity of eternal darkness, trying to escape from The Void. Born finds himself in Nihilumbra (meaning "the shadow of nothing," from nihil, nothing, and umbra, shadow), the ruins of a world once inhabited by whom one can only speculate. This is one of the most thought provoking games ever.

												It's a really cute game and perfect to play when you are bored or something, it's not that hard but yet a challenge!It's totally worth the prize, you won't regred itThe story is not just fascinating and imaginative, but also really sweet and instructive!

Posted: July 10, 2016
												I initially bought this game just because it was on sale, but it turned out to be one of the more imaginative games i've seen in a while. As soon as the game started, I was thrown into a world of beautiful artwork and music. I also loved the main character, despite it being little more than a blob. The narrator (whose voice resembles that of Morgan Freeman) plays very well into the overall atmosphere, which can vary from charming to downright unsettleing. This is an amazing indie game that obviosly had a lot of love put into it and deserves more attention. My only complaint is that the puzzles leave something to be desired, as I solved most of them almost instantly. Overall, I'd give this game 4/5 stars

Posted: May 28, 2016
												Good game, though it often pretends to be more profound than it actually is. It often breaks the age old rule of "show, don't tell."The puzzles themselves are often too easy, though I also would like there to be an option to disable hints (maybe there is, couldn't find it) because the hints that there are just give away the solution.Still, I'd recommend this game.

Posted: June 12, 2016
												A clever puzzle-platformer based on "colors" mechanic -- think gels from Portal 2. First half of the game feels to easy, but the difficulty builds up as you reach the "Void" chapters -- those bring both some brain-teasers and tricky action sequences. The visual style is pleasant, and the story is simple, but touching. Not a masterpiece, but a strong, solid example of the genre.

Posted: December 18, 2016
												The first playthrough is only around 2.5 hours and is fun and mildly/comfortably challenging, but the second playthrough in Void Mode is where the game shines (challenge-wise). While Void Mode goes through the same landscapes, the puzzles are different: Braid/Portal levels of complexity/challenge (judging from the first 6% I've played of it so far), and I get the feeling this mode will take at least twice as long to finish, so at least 8 hours' worth of fun gameplay. It has a basic story, which I was indifferent to, but other reviewers seem to like it. For me, the story neither helped nor hindered the game. The narration can be turned off.Highly recommended.

Posted: December 23, 2016
												The first part of Nihilumbra feels almost too easy, but once you reach Void Mode things really heat up and the game becomes much more difficult.  I am thoroughly enjoying Void Mode and, as I beat each level, the feeling of accomplishment from beating the puzzles.  :)The music, narration, art, and gameplay come together perfectly to create an environment that I quickly became attached to.  10/10 would recommend!On a personal note, I played Nihilumbra at the perfect time in my life; the story, while minimal, resonated with my struggle with depression and anxiety.  Escaping the Void (depression) and slowly learning different abilities (ways to cope) helped me see that there is a way to beat the depression I'm fighting against and become my own person.
